lines.value: a flatboat is a rectangular flat bottomed boat with <ref name="janesfbhist"> square ends used to transport freight and passengers on inland waterways
lines.name: English

lines.value: the flatboat could be any size but essentially it is large sturdy tub with a hull
lines.name: English

lines.value: a flatboat is almost always a one way vessel and is usually dismantled for lumber when it reaches its downstream destination
lines.name: English

lines.value: the flatboat trade first began in 1781 with pennsylvania farmer jacob yoder building the first flatboat at old redstone fort on the mononganhela river
lines.name: English

lines.value: yoder shipped flour down the mississippi river to the port of new orleans
lines.name: English

lines.value: other flatboats would follow this model using the current of the river to propel them to new orleans where their final product could be shipped overseas
lines.name: English

lines.value: through the antebellum period flatboats were one of the most important modes of shipping in the united states
lines.name: English

lines.value: the flatboat trade before the war of 1812 was less organized and less professional than during later times
lines.name: English

lines.value: flatboats were generally built and piloted by the farmers whose crops they carried
lines.name: English

lines.value: they were limited to 20 feet or approximately 6 meters in width in order to successfully navigate the river but could range from 20 to 100 feet or approximately 6 to 30 meters in length
lines.name: English

lines.value: flatboats could be built by unskilled farmers with limited tools and training making them an ideal mode of transport for isolated farmers living in the old northwest and the upper south
lines.name: English

lines.value: farmers could make the journey down the river after the harvest
lines.name: English

lines.value: the boats themselves were usually salvaged for lumber at new orleans because they could not easily make the journey upriver
lines.name: English

lines.value: a boatman's return journey up the river was long and usually arduous
lines.name: English

lines.value: passage on a human-powered keelboat was expensive and took weeks to make the journey up the mississippi
lines.name: English

lines.value: returning to northern reaches on foot required about three months
lines.name: English

lines.value: a flatboat itself was a serious investment for a midwestern farmer
lines.name: English

lines.value: one generally cost about $75 to construct in 1800 which was ), but could carry up to $3000 worth of goods
lines.name: English

lines.value: these flatboats could typically be salvaged for around $16 in new orleans recouping some of the initial investment
lines.name: English

lines.value: flatboats carried a variety of goods to new orleans including agricultural products like corn wheat potatoes flour hay tobacco cotton and whiskey
lines.name: English

lines.value: livestock such as chickens cows and pigs also made their way down the mississippi in flatboats
lines.name: English

lines.value: indiana native may espey warren recalled seeing a flatboat loaded with thousands of chickens headed down the mississippi as a young girl
lines.name: English

lines.value: other raw materials from the old northwest like lumber and iron were also sent down the mississippi to be sold in new orleans
lines.name: English

lines.value: many american cities along the river network of the mississippi boomed due to the opportunities that the flatboat trade presented
lines.name: English

lines.value: new orleans was the final destination for most flatboats headed down the mississippi and it was there that most of the goods were shipped on the oceans
lines.name: English

lines.value: cincinnati another major american trading city first built itself on the flatboat trade
lines.name: English

lines.value: its large sawmills produced most of the heavy lumber sent down on flatboats and it also became a large hub for the pork trade
lines.name: English

lines.value: other cities like memphis tennessee and brownsville pennsylvania became hubs for outfitting and supplying flatboat traders
lines.name: English

lines.value: the flatboat trade also led to a series of cultural and regional exchange between the north and the south
lines.name: English

lines.value: many northern flatboatmen had not seen the southern united states before and rural farmers of the time generally did not travel
lines.name: English

lines.value: flatboatmen brought tales of antebellum mansions lining the mississippi and of the cajun culture of lower louisiana
lines.name: English

lines.value: they also brought back exotic foods such as bananas and animals such as parrots
lines.name: English

lines.value: abraham lincoln served as a flatboatman twice in 1828 and 1831
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was on this journey that he first witnessed slavery and in new orleans he also saw a slave auction firsthand
lines.name: English

lines.value: lincoln would later recall these journeys as essential in shaping his personal views on slavery and the slave trade
lines.name: English

lines.value: the invention of the steamboat greatly reduced the costs of flatboat journeys and caused the trade to boom through the antebellum period
lines.name: English

lines.value: the steamboat introduced to the mississippi in the 1810s greatly reduced the time of the return journey for flatboat crews
lines.name: English

lines.value: after reaching new orleans many flatboat crews scuttled their craft and bought passage on steamboats upriver
lines.name: English

lines.value: what had once been a three month hike for many flatboaters now took only days
lines.name: English

lines.value: these reduced labor costs saw flatboat labor costs plummet and profits boom
lines.name: English

lines.value: in some cases steamboats would also drag flatboats bringing cargo upriver allowing flatboat operators to profit on the return journey as well
lines.name: English

lines.value: the utilization of steamboats caused the flatboat industry to increase from 598 arrivals in new orleans in 1814 to 2792 in 1847
lines.name: English

lines.value: the steamboat also changed the nature of flatboat crews making them more professional and more skilled
lines.name: English

lines.value: steamboats allowed flatboat crews to make multiple journeys per year meaning that a crew could earn a living wage simply by flatboating
lines.name: English

lines.value: these crews were known as agent boatmen as opposed to the earlier dealer boatmen or peddler boatmen for whom flatboating was only a seasonal job
lines.name: English

lines.value: this change ended up benefitting the flatboat industry significantly because it seriously reduced wreckages and lost cargo
lines.name: English

lines.value: along with river improvements experienced flatboat crews were able to reduce cargo losses from $1362500 in 1822 to $381000 in 1832
lines.name: English

lines.value: the flatboat trade stayed vibrant and lucrative throughout the antebellum period and was aided by steamboats and later railroads in returning crews upriver
lines.name: English

lines.value: however these technologies which earlier made the flatboat trade significantly more efficient would eventually overtake the flatboat trade along the mississippi and render flatboats obsolete
lines.name: English

lines.value: steamboats and railroads simply carried freight much more quickly than flatboats and could bring cargo upriver as well as downriver
lines.name: English

lines.value: by 1857 only 541 flatboats reached new orleans down from 2792 in 1847 and even lower than the 598 flatboats that travelled down the mississippi in 1814
lines.name: English

lines.value: shalimar the clown is a 2005 novel by salman rushdie

lines.value: shalimar the clown derives its name from shalimar gardens in the vicinity of srinagar
lines.name: English

lines.value: srinagar is one of several mughal gardens which were laid out in several parts of undivided india when the mughals reigned over the subcontinent
lines.name: English

lines.value: shalimar is also the name of one of the characters featured in the novel
lines.name: English

lines.value: shalimar the clown won the 2005 vodafone crossword book award and was one of the finalists for the 2005 whitbread book awards

lines.value: the novel is based partly in a small town in the region of kashmir
lines.name: English

lines.value: the town itself is imaginary but it is located in an accurate geographic location not far from srinagar
lines.name: English

lines.value: the title refers to a character in the story a kashmiri villager named shalimar who performs a tightrope act for the amusement of the other villagers
lines.name: English

lines.value: the central character india is the illegitimate child of a former united states ambassador to india maximilian ophuls
lines.name: English

lines.value: although a number of narratives and incidents in the novel revolve around kashmir the novel opens in los angeles
lines.name: English

lines.value: max ophuls a us diplomat who has worked in the kashmir valley is murdered by his former chauffeur shalimar
lines.name: English

lines.value: several flashbacks take the readers to the past and one learns that shalimar was once full of affection love and laughter
lines.name: English

lines.value: he lived in the fictional kashmiri village of pachigam
lines.name: English

lines.value: his skill on the tight rope has earned him renown in his village and the nickname shalimar the clown
lines.name: English

lines.value: at a young age he falls in love with a beautiful kashmiri pandit girl named boonyi
lines.name: English

lines.value: the village elders agree to the marriage and all seems fine except that boonyi doesn't want to remain stuck in this small village
lines.name: English

lines.value: things come to a head when maximilian comes to the village sees boonyi dance and becomes enamored of her
lines.name: English

lines.value: with the help of his assistant he gets her a flat in delhi and an affair blossoms
lines.name: English

lines.value: a scandal erupts when boonyi gets pregnant and max is forced to return
lines.name: English

lines.value: the child india is brought to england by maximilian's wife
lines.name: English

lines.value: shalimar was deeply in love with boonyi and couldn't bear her betrayal
lines.name: English

lines.value: he devotes the rest of his life to taking revenge on the people that were the cause of his unhappiness
lines.name: English

lines.value: for this purpose he joins up with various jihadi organisations and becomes a renowned assassin
lines.name: English

lines.value: maximilian the son of ashkenazi jews was raised in france
lines.name: English

lines.value: following the death of his parents in a nazi concentration camp he becomes a hero of the french resistance
lines.name: English

lines.value: a fictionalised account of the bugatti automobile company plays a role in his escape from the nazis
lines.name: English

lines.value: following the war he marries a british aristocrat and eventually becomes american ambassador to india
lines.name: English

lines.value: this appointment eventually leads to his unspecified role in relation to american counter terrorism
lines.name: English

lines.value: the appointment is more important than his ambassadorship but his exact role is left vague
lines.name: English

lines.value: shalimar receives training from insurgent groups in afghanistan and the philippines and leaves for the usa
lines.name: English

lines.value: he murders max on the day he resigns as his driver
lines.name: English

lines.value: shalimar evades the authorities and eventually returns to india's home with the intention of killing her

lines.value: donald allen wollheim october 1 1914 - november 2 1990 was an american science fiction editor publisher writer and fan
lines.name: English

lines.value: as an author he published under his own name as well as under pseudonyms including david grinnell
lines.name: English

lines.value: a founding member of the futurians he was a leading influence on science fiction development and fandom in the 20th century united states
lines.name: English

lines.value: ursula k le guin called wollheim the tough reliable editor of ace books in the late pulpalignean era 1966 and 67 " which is when he published her first two novels in an ace double
lines.name: English

lines.value: the encyclopedia of science fiction first edition 1979 calls wollheim one of the first and most vociferous sf fans he published numerous fanzines and co edited the early fanciful tales of space and time
lines.name: English

lines.value: his importance to early fandom is chronicled in the 1974 book the immortal storm by sam moskowitz and in the 1977 book the futurians by damon knight
lines.name: English

lines.value: wollheim organized the first science fiction convention when a group from new york met with a group from philadelphia on october 22 1936 in philadelphia
lines.name: English

lines.value: the modern philcon convention claims descent from this event
lines.name: English

lines.value: out of this meeting plans were formed for regional and national meetings including the first worldcon
lines.name: English

lines.value: wollheim was a member of the new york science fiction league one of the clubs established by hugo gernsback to promote science fiction
lines.name: English

lines.value: when payment was not forthcoming for the first story he sold to gernsback wollheim formed a group with several other authors and successfully sued for payment
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was expelled from the science fiction league as a disruptive influence but was later reinstated
lines.name: English

lines.value: from the september 1935 issue of gernsback's wonder stories in 1937 wollheim founded the fantasy amateur press association whose first mailing july 1937 included this statement from him there are many fans desiring to put out a voice who dare not for fear of being obliged to keep it up and for the worry and time taken by subscriptions and advertising
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is for them and for the fan who admits it is his hobby and not his business that we formed the fapa in 1938 with several friends he formed the futurians arguably the best known of the science fiction clubs
lines.name: English

lines.value: at one time or another the membership included isaac asimov frederik pohl cyril kornbluth james blish john michel judith merril robert a w lowndes richard wilson damon knight virginia kidd and larry t shaw
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1943 wollheim married fellow futurian elsie balter 1910-1996
lines.name: English

lines.value: it proved to be a lasting marriage and a publishing partnership
lines.name: English

lines.value: the futurians became less fan oriented and more professional after 1940
lines.name: English

lines.value: its conferences and workshops focused on writing editing and publishing with many of its members interested in all three
lines.name: English

lines.value: wollheim's first story the man from ariel was published in the january 1934 issue of wonder stories when he was nineteen
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was not paid for the story and when he learned that other authors had not been paid either he said so in the bulletin of the terrestrial fantascience guild
lines.name: English

lines.value: publisher hugo gernsback eventually settled with wollheim and the other authors out of court for $75
lines.name: English

lines.value: however when wollheim submitted another story the space lens under the pseudonym millard verne gordon he was once again cheated by gernsback who published it in the september 1935 issue
lines.name: English

lines.value: his third known story was published in fanciful tales of time and space fall 1936 a fanzine that he edited himself
lines.name: English

lines.value: that year he also published and edited another short lived fanzine phantagraph
lines.name: English

lines.value: wollheim's stories were published regularly from 1940 at the same time he was becoming an important editor
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the 1950s and 60s he wrote chiefly novels
lines.name: English

lines.value: he usually used pseudonyms for works aimed at grownups and wrote children's novels under his own name
lines.name: English

lines.value: notable and popular were the eight mike mars books for children which explored different facets of the nasa space program
lines.name: English

lines.value: also well received were the secret books for young readers the secret of saturn's rings 1954 secret of the martian moons 1955 and the secret of the ninth planet 1959
lines.name: English

lines.value: as martin pearson he published the ajax calkins series which became the basis for his novel destiny's orbit 1962
lines.name: English

lines.value: a sequel destination saturn was published in 1967 in collaboration with lin carter
lines.name: English

lines.value: the universe makers 1971 is a discussion of themes and philosophy in science fiction
lines.name: English

lines.value: one of wollheim's short stories mimic was made into the feature film of the same name released in 1997
lines.name: English

lines.value: his daughter betsy declared in true editorial fashion he was honest about the quality of his own writing
lines.name: English

lines.value: he felt it was fair to middling at best
lines.name: English

lines.value: he always knew that his great talent was as an editor
lines.name: English

lines.value: robert silverberg said that wollheim was one of the most significant figures in 20th century american science fiction publishing adding a plausible case could be made that he was the most significant figure - responsible in large measure for the development of the science fiction paperback the science fiction anthology and the whole post tolkien boom in fantasy fiction in late 1940 wollheim noticed a new magazine titled stirring detective and western stories on the newsstands
lines.name: English

lines.value: he wrote to the publishers albing publications to see if they were interested in adding a science fiction title to their list and he was invited to meet them
lines.name: English

lines.value: they did not have capital however and only guaranteed him a salary if the magazines were successful
lines.name: English

lines.value: he approached some of his fellow futurians for free stories some published under pseudonyms to protect their reputations with paying editors
lines.name: English

lines.value: it resulted in wollheim's editing two of the earliest periodicals devoted to science fiction the cosmic stories and stirring science stories magazines starting in february 1941
lines.name: English

lines.value: after the magazines were cancelled later in 1941 wollheim was able to find another publisher manhattan fiction publications and a fourth issue of stirring appeared dated march 1942
lines.name: English

lines.value: wartime constraints prevented ongoing publication and there were no more issues of either title
lines.name: English

lines.value: wollheim edited the first science fiction anthology to be mass marketed the pocket book of science fiction 1943
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was also the first book containing the words science fiction in the title
lines.name: English

lines.value: it included works by robert a heinlein theodore sturgeon t s stribling stephen vincent benet ambrose bierce and h g wells
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1945 wollheim edited the first hardcover anthology from a major publisher and the first omnibus the viking portable novels of science
lines.name: English

lines.value: he also edited the first anthology of original science fiction the girl with the hungry eyes 1947 although there is evidence that this last was originally intended to be the first issue of a new magazine
lines.name: English

lines.value: between 1947 and 1951 he was editor at the pioneering paperback publisher avon books where he made available highly affordable editions of the works of a merritt h p lovecraft and c s lewis silent planet space trilogy bringing these previously little known authors a wide readership
lines.name: English

lines.value: during this period he also edited eighteen issues of the influential avon fantasy reader as well as three of the avon science fiction reader
lines.name: English

lines.value: these periodicals contained mostly reprints and a few original stories
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1952 wollheim left avon to work for a a wyn at the ace magazine company and spearheaded a new paperback book list ace books
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1953 he introduced science fiction to the ace lineup and for 20 years as editor in chief was responsible for their multi genre list and most important to him their renowned sf list
lines.name: English

lines.value: wollheim invented the ace doubles series which consisted of pairs of books usually by different authors bound back to back with two front covers

lines.value: edmund rudiger stoiber born 28 september 1941 is a german politician who was the 16th minister president of the state of bavaria between 1993 and 2007 and chairman of the christian social union csu between 1998 and 2007
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2002 he candidated for the office of chancellor of germany in the federal election but in one of the narrowest elections in german history lost against gerhard schroder
lines.name: English

lines.value: on 18 january 2007 he announced his decision to step down from the posts of minister president and party chairman by 30 september after having been under fire in his own party for weeks
lines.name: English

lines.value: edmund stoiber was born in oberaudorf in the district of rosenheim bavaria
lines.name: English

lines.value: prior to entering politics in 1974 and serving in the bavarian parliament he was a lawyer and worked at the university of regensburg
lines.name: English

lines.value: stoiber attended the ignaz gunther gymnasium in rosenheim where he received his abitur high school diploma in 1961 although he had to repeat one year for failing in latin
lines.name: English

lines.value: his national service was with the gebirgsdivision mountain infantry division in mittenwald and bad reichenhall and was cut short due to a knee injury
lines.name: English

lines.value: following his military service stoiber studied political science and then in the fall 1962 in munich law
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1967 he passed the state law exam and then worked at the university of regensburg in criminal law and eastern european law
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was awarded a doctorate of jurisprudence and then in 1971 passed the second state examination with distinction
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1971 stoiber joined the bavarian state ministry of development and environment
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1978 stoiber was elected secretary general of the csu a post he held until 1982/83
lines.name: English

lines.value: in this capacity he served as campaign manager of franz josef strauss the first bavarian leader to run for the chancellorship in the 1980 national elections
lines.name: English

lines.value: from 1982 to 1986 he served as deputy to the bavarian secretary of the state and then in the position of state minister led the state chancellery from 1982 to 1988
lines.name: English

lines.value: from 1988 to 1993 he served as state minister of the interior
lines.name: English

lines.value: in may 1993 the landtag of bavaria the state's parliament elected stoiber as minister president succeeding max streibl
lines.name: English

lines.value: he came to power amid a political crisis involving a sex scandal surrounding a contender for the state premiership
lines.name: English

lines.value: upon taking office he nominated strauss daughter monika hohlmeier as state minister for education and cultural affairs
lines.name: English

lines.value: in his capacity as minister president stoiber served as president of the bundesrat in 1995/96
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1998 he also succeeded theo waigel as chairman of the csu
lines.name: English

lines.value: during stoiber's 14 years leading bavaria the state solidified its position as one of germany's richest
lines.name: English

lines.value: already by 1998 under his leadership the state had privatized more than $3 billion worth of state owned businesses and used that money to invest in new infrastructure and provide venture capital for new companies
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was widely regarded a central figure in building one of europe's most powerful regional economies attracting thousands of hi tech engineering and media companies and reducing unemployment to half the national average
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2002 stoiber politically outmaneuvered cdu chairwoman angela merkel and was declared the cdu/csu's candidate for the office of chancellor by practically the entire leadership of the csu's sister party cdu challenging gerhard schroder
lines.name: English

lines.value: at that time merkel had generally been seen as a transitional chair and was strongly opposed by the cdu's male leaders often called the party's crown princes
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the run up to the 2002 national elections the csu/cdu held a huge lead in the opinion polls and stoiber famously remarked that ...this election is like a football match where it's the second half and my team is ahead by 2 0 however on election day things had changed
lines.name: English

lines.value: the spd had mounted a huge comeback and the cdu/csu was narrowly defeated though both the spd and cdu/csu had 38.5% of the vote the spd was ahead by a small 6000 vote margin winning 251 seats to the cdu/csu's 248
lines.name: English

lines.value: the election was one of modern germany's closest votes
lines.name: English

lines.value: gerhard schroder was reelected as chancellor by the parliament in a coalition with the greens who had increased their vote share marginally
lines.name: English

lines.value: many commentators faulted stoiber's reaction to the floods in eastern germany in the run up to the election as a contributory factor in his party's poor electoral result and defeat
lines.name: English

lines.value: in addition schroder distinguished himself from his opponent by taking an active stance against the upcoming united states led iraq war
lines.name: English

lines.value: his extensive campaigning on this stance was widely seen as swinging the election to the spd in the weeks running up to the election
lines.name: English

lines.value: stoiber subsequently led the csu to an absolute majority in the 2003 bavarian state elections for the third time in a row winning this time 607% of the votes and a two thirds majority in the landtag
lines.name: English

lines.value: this was the widest margin ever achieved by a german party in any state
lines.name: English

lines.value: between 2003 and 2004 stoiber served as co chair alongside franz muntefering of the first commission on the modernization of the federal state foderalismuskommission i which had been established to reform the division of powers between federal and state authorities in germany
lines.name: English

lines.value: in february 2004 he became a candidate of jacques chirac and gerhard schroder for the presidency of the european commission but he decided not to run for this office
lines.name: English

lines.value: stoiber had ambitions to run again for the chancellorship but merkel secured the nomination and in november 2005 she won the general election
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was slated to join merkel's first grand coalition cabinet as economics minister
lines.name: English

lines.value: however on 1 november 2005 he announced his decision to stay in bavaria due to personnel changes on the spd side of the coalition franz muntefering resigned as spd chairman and an unsatisfactory apportionment of competences between himself and designated science minister annette schavan
lines.name: English

lines.value: stoiber also resigned his seat in the 16th bundestag being a member from 18 october to 8 november
lines.name: English

lines.value: subsequently criticism grew in the csu where other politicians had to scale back their ambitions after stoiber's decision to stay in bavaria
lines.name: English

lines.value: on 18 january 2007 he announced his decision to stand down from the posts of minister president and party chairman by 30 september
lines.name: English

lines.value: gunther beckstein then bavarian state minister of the interior succeeded him as minister president and erwin huber as party chairman defeating horst seehofer at a convention at 18 september 2007 with 581% of the votes
lines.name: English

lines.value: both beckstein and huber resigned after the 2008 state elections in which the csu vote dropped to 434% and the party had to form a coalition with another party for the first time since 1966
lines.name: English

lines.value: stoiber was first appointed in 2007 as a special adviser to then european commission president jose manuel barroso to chair the high level group on administrative burdens made up of national experts ngos business and industry organizations
lines.name: English

lines.value: quickly nicknamed the stoiber group it produced a report in july 2014 with several proposals on streamlining the regulatory process
lines.name: English

lines.value: stoiber was reappointed in december 2014 by jean claude juncker to the same role from which he resigned after one year in late 2015
lines.name: English

lines.value: since his retirement from german politics in 2007 stoiber has worked as a lawyer and held paid and unpaid positions including
lines.name: English

lines.value: in his capacity as minister president stoiber made 58 foreign trips including to china 1995 2003 israel 2001 egypt 2001 india 2004 2007 and south korea 2007

lines.value: in 2002 stoiber publicly expressed support for the united states in their policy toward iraq
lines.name: English

lines.value: during his election campaign he made clear his opposition to war and his support for the introduction of weapons inspectors to iraq without preconditions as a way of avoiding war and he criticized schroder for harming the german american alliance by not calling president george w bush and discussing the issue privately
lines.name: English

lines.value: he also attacked german foreign minister joschka fischer for his criticism of the us position
lines.name: English

lines.value: stoiber is known for backing vladimir putin and there have been comparisons to gerhard schroder
lines.name: English

lines.value: one author called stoiber a moscow's trojan horse
lines.name: English

lines.value: putin is known to have given stoiber extreme forms of flattery and privileges such as a private dinner at putin's residence outside moscow
lines.name: English

lines.name: English

lines.value: when the european commission recommended that greece be allowed to join the eurozone in 1998 he demanded that the country be barred from adopting the common currency for several years instead
lines.name: English

lines.value: he is a staunch opponent of turkey's integration into the european union claiming that its non christian culture would dilute the union
lines.name: English

lines.value: at the same time stoiber has repeatedly insisted he is a good european who is keen for instance on forging an eu wide foreign policy replete with a single european army
lines.name: English

lines.value: earlier in 1993 he had told german newspapers i want a simple confederation
lines.name: English

lines.value: that means the nation states maintain their dominant role at least as far as internal matters are concerned
lines.name: English

lines.value: while the conservative wing of the german political spectrum primarily formed of the cdu and csu enjoys considerable support this support tends to be less extended to stoiber
lines.name: English

lines.value: he enjoys considerably more support in his home state of bavaria than in the rest of germany where cdu chairwoman angela merkel is more popular
lines.name: English

lines.value: this has its reasons merkel supports a kind of fiscal conservatism but a more liberal social policy
lines.name: English

lines.value: stoiber on the other hand favors a more conservative approach to both fiscal and social matters and while this ensures him the religious vote strongest in bavaria it has weakened his support at the national level
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2005 stoiber successfully lobbied novartis the swiss pharmaceuticals group to move the headquarters of its sandoz subsidiary to munich making it one of europe's highest profile corporate relocations that year as well as a significant boost to stoiber's attempts to build up bavaria as a pharmaceuticals and biotechnology center
lines.name: English

lines.value: during his time as minister president of bavaria stoiber pushed for the construction of a roughly 40-kilometer high speed magnetic levitation link from munich's main station to its airport to be built by transrapid international a consortium including thyssenkrupp and munich based siemens
lines.name: English

lines.value: after he left office the german federal government abandoned the plans in 2008 because of spiraling costs of as much as 3.4 billion
lines.name: English

lines.value: stoiber as a minister in the state of bavaria was widely known for advocating a reduction in the number of asylum seekers germany accepts something that prompted critics to label him xenophobic anti turkish and anti islam
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the late 1990s he criticized the incoming chancellor schroder for saying that he would work hard in the interest of germans and people living in germany
lines.name: English

lines.value: stoiber's remarks drew heavy criticism in the press
lines.name: English

lines.value: when germany's federal constitutional court decided in 1995 that a bavarian law requiring a crucifix to be hung in each of the state's 40000 classrooms was unconstitutional stoiber said he would not order the removal of crucifixes for the time being and asserted that he was under no obligation to remove them in schools where parents unanimously opposed such action
lines.name: English

lines.name: English

lines.value: however when european commissioner for competition karel van miert unveiled ideas for reforming the rules governing the financing of public service broadcasters in 1998 stoiber led the way in rejecting moves to reform established practice

lines.value: during the run up to the german general election in 2005 which was held ahead of schedule stoiber created controversy through a campaign speech held in the beginning of august 2005 in the federal state of baden wurttemberg

lines.value: he said i do not accept that the east [of germany] will again decide who will be germany's chancellor

lines.value: unfortunately not everyone in germany is as intelligent as in bavaria the tone of the comments was exacerbated by a perception by some within germany of the state of bavaria as arrogant

lines.value: many including members of the cdu attribute stoiber's comments and behavior as a contributing factor to the cdu's losses in the 2005 general election

lines.value: he was accused by many in the cdu/csu of offering half hearted support to angela merkel with some even accusing him of being reluctant to support a female candidate from the east

lines.value: christian iii 12 august 1503 - 1 january 1559 reigned as king of denmark from 1534 until his death and king of norway from 1537 until his death
lines.name: English

lines.value: during his reign christian established lutheranism as the state religion within his realms as part of the protestant reformation
lines.name: English

lines.value: christian was the eldest son of future king frederick i of denmark and anna of brandenburg
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was born at gottorf castle which frederick i had made as a primary residence
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1514 when he was just ten years old christian's mother died
lines.name: English

lines.value: four years later his father remarried to sophie of pomerania 1498-1568
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1523 frederick i was elected king of denmark in the place of his nephew king christian ii of denmark
lines.name: English

lines.value: the young prince christian's first public service after his father became king was gaining the submission of copenhagen which stood firm for the fugitive king christian ii
lines.name: English

lines.value: as stadtholder of the duchies of holstein and schleswig in 1526 and as viceroy of norway in 1529 christian iii displayed considerable administrative ability
lines.name: English

lines.value: christian's earliest teacher wolfgang von utenhof and his lutheran tutor the military general johann rantzau were both zealous reformers who had an influence on the young prince
lines.name: English

lines.value: at their urging while traveling in germany in 1521 he made himself present at the diet of worms to hear martin luther speak
lines.name: English

lines.value: luther's arguments intrigued him
lines.name: English

lines.value: the prince made no secret of his lutheran views
lines.name: English

lines.value: his outspokenness brought him into conflict not only with the roman catholic rigsraad but also with his cautious and temporizing father
lines.name: English

lines.value: at his own court at schleswig he did his best to introduce the protestant reformation despite the opposition of the bishops
lines.name: English

lines.value: when he imposed the reformation at haderslev in 1526 he took up residence at haderslevhus castle
lines.name: English

lines.value: he made the lutheran church the state church of schleswig holstein with the church ordinance of 1528
lines.name: English

lines.value: after his father's death in 1533 christian was proclaimed king at an assembly in rye a town in eastern jutland in 1534
lines.name: English

lines.value: the danish state council rigsraad dominated by roman catholic bishops and nobles refused to accept duke christian as king and turned to count christopher of oldenburg in order to restore christian ii to the danish throne
lines.name: English

lines.value: christian ii had supported both the roman catholics and protestant reformers at various times
lines.name: English

lines.value: in opposition to king christian iii count christopher was proclaimed regent at the ringsted assembly landsting and at the skane assembly ( landsting on st liber's hill at lund cathedral
lines.name: English

lines.value: this resulted in a two year civil war known as the count's feud grevens fejde 1534 36 between protestant and catholic forces
lines.name: English

lines.value: count christopher had the support of most of zealand scania the hanseatic league and the small farmers of northern jutland and funen
lines.name: English

lines.value: christian iii found his support among the nobles of jutland
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1534 peasants under skipper clement began an uprising in northern jutland pillaging the holdings of lutheran nobles
lines.name: English

lines.value: an army of nobles and their vassals assembled at svendstrup and suffered a terrible defeat at the hands of the peasants
lines.name: English

lines.value: realizing his hold on the throne was in imminent danger christian iii negotiated a deal with the hansa states which allowed him to send his trusted advisor johan rantzau north with an army of protestant german mercenaries
lines.name: English

lines.value: clement and his army fled north taking refuge inside the walls of aalborg
lines.name: English

lines.value: in december rantzau's forces breached the walls and stormed the city
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the following days 3000 people were massacred and the city was plundered by the protestant german mercenaries
lines.name: English

lines.value: clement managed to escape the slaughter but was apprehended a few days later
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was tried and beheaded in 1535
lines.name: English

lines.value: with jutland more or less secure christian next focused on gaining control of scania
lines.name: English

lines.value: he appealed to the protestant swedish king gustav vasa for help in subduing the rebels
lines.name: English

lines.value: gustav immediately obliged by sending two armies to ravage central scania and halland
lines.name: English

lines.value: the peasants suffered a bloody defeat at loshult in scania
lines.name: English

lines.value: the swedes moved against helsingborg castle which surrendered in january 1535 and was burned to the ground
lines.name: English

lines.value: rantzau moved his army to funen and defeated count christopher's army at oksnebjerg in june 1535
lines.name: English

lines.value: count christopher's forces held out in malmo and copenhagen until july 1536 when they surrendered after several months of siege by christian iii's forces
lines.name: English

lines.value: with their capitulation christian iii was firmly placed upon denmark's throne and the roman catholic forces in denmark were subdued
lines.name: English

lines.value: a mutual confidence between a king who had conquered his kingdom and a people who had stood in arms against him was not attainable immediately
lines.name: English

lines.value: the circumstances under which christian iii ascended the throne exposed denmark to the danger of foreign domination
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was with the help of the gentry of the germanic duchies that christian had captured denmark
lines.name: English

lines.value: holstein and german noblemen had led his armies and directed his diplomacy
lines.name: English

lines.value: the first six years of christian iii's reign were marked by a contest between the danish rigsraadet and the german counsellors both of whom sought to rule through the king
lines.name: English

lines.value: though the danish party won a victory at the outset by obtaining the insertion in the charter of provisions stipulating that only native born danes should fill the highest dignities of the state the king's german counsellors continued paramount during his early reign
lines.name: English

lines.value: the triumph of christian iii would eventually bring about an end to catholic christianity in denmark but roman catholics still controlled the council of state
lines.name: English

lines.value: christian iii ordered the arrest of three of the bishops on the state council by his german mercenaries 12 august 1536
lines.name: English

lines.value: christian's debt for the count's feud was enormous and confiscating the church lands farmed by peasants who had been free from vassalage duties to the nobles enabled him to pay down the debt to his creditors
lines.name: English

lines.value: the ultimate gainers from the confiscations were the nobles who led the new faith imported from germany
lines.name: English

lines.value: christian's protestant policies led denmark toward the establishment of lutheranism as the danish national church folkekirke
lines.name: English

lines.value: this occurred officially on 30 october 1536 when the reconstituted state council adopted the lutheran ordinances designed by johannes bugenhagen which outlined church organization liturgy and accepted religious practice
lines.name: English

lines.value: monasteries nunneries and priories were closed and the property taken by the crown see chronicle of the expulsion of the grayfriars
lines.name: English

lines.value: vast tracts of land were handed out to the king's supporters
lines.name: English

lines.value: churches were closed cathedral schools terminated and recalcitrant priests turned out of their parishes
lines.name: English

lines.value: bishops were imprisoned until they agreed to marry and give up their privileges
lines.name: English

lines.value: some submitted after years of imprisonment others refused to accept and became martyrs to their beliefs
lines.name: English

lines.value: the dangers threatening christian iii from charles v holy roman emperor and other kinsmen of the imprisoned christian ii convinced him of the necessity to lessen the discontent in the land by relying on danish magnates and nobles
lines.name: English

lines.value: at the herredag of copenhagen in 1542 the nobility of denmark voted christian a twentieth part of all their property to pay off his heavy debt to german mercenaries
lines.name: English

lines.value: the pivot of the foreign policy of christian iii was his alliance with the german protestant princes
lines.name: English

lines.value: this provided a counterpoise to the persistent hostility of charles v who was determined to support the hereditary claims of his nieces the daughters of christian ii to the scandinavian kingdoms
lines.name: English

lines.value: war was declared against charles v in 1542 and though the german protestant princes proved faithless allies the closing of the sound against dutch shipping proved such an effective weapon in king christian's hand that the netherlands compelled charles v to make peace with denmark at the diet of speyer on 23 may 1544
lines.name: English

lines.value: until this peace christian iii ruled the entire duchies of holstein and of schleswig also in the name of his then still minor half brothers john the elder hans den aldre and adolf
lines.name: English

lines.value: they determined their youngest brother frederick for a career as diocesan administrator of an ecclesiastical state within the holy roman empire
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1544 the elder three brothers partitioned holstein a fief of the holy roman empire and schleswig a danish fief in an unusual way following negotiations between the brothers and the estates of the realm of the duchies which opposed a factual partition
lines.name: English

lines.value: so the revenues of the duchies were divided into three equal shares by assigning the revenues of particular areas and landed estates to each of the three brothers while other general revenues such as taxes from towns and customs dues were levied together but then shared among the brothers
lines.name: English

lines.value: the estates whose revenues were assigned to the parties made holstein and schleswig look like patchworks technically inhibiting the emergence of separate new duchies as intended by the estates of the duchies
lines.name: English

lines.value: the secular rule in the fiscally divided duchies thus became a international law condominium of the parties
lines.name: English

lines.value: as an effect both separate duchies holstein and schleswig with shares of each party scattered in both duchies provided them with a condominial government binding both together partially superseding their legally different affiliation as holy roman and danish fiefs
lines.name: English

lines.value: as dukes of holstein and schleswig the three brothers bore the formal title of duke of schleswig holstein ditmarsh and stormarn
lines.name: English

lines.value: john the elder conveniently called duke of schleswig holstein haderslev produced no issue so no branch emerged from his side
lines.name: English

lines.value: adolf founded a cadet branch of the royal danish house of oldenburg called house of holstein gottorp a convenient usage for the technically more correct duke of schleswig and holstein at gottorp
lines.name: English

lines.value: similarly christian iii's youngest son john the younger gained for himself and his heirs a share in holstein's and schleswig's revenues in 1564 comprising a third of the royal share a ninth of holstein and schleswig from a fiscal point of view
lines.name: English

lines.value: john the younger and his heirs however had no share in the condominial rule
lines.name: English

lines.value: the foreign policy of king christian's later days was regulated by peace following the treaty of speyer 1544
lines.name: English

lines.value: he carefully avoided all foreign complications refused to participate in the schmalkaldic war of 1546 mediated between the emperor and saxony after the fall of maurice of saxony at the battle of sievershausen in 1553
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1549 he began the building of landskrona citadel
lines.name: English

lines.value: he also rebuilt sonderborg castle converting it from a fortress into a four winged castle in the new renaissance syle between 1549 and 1557
lines.name: English

lines.value: in february 1555 he interceded successfully on the behalf of the english bible translator miles coverdale who had been imprisoned for two and a half years by queen mary i of england
lines.name: English

lines.value: coverdale was then released and allowed to leave england
lines.name: English

lines.value: king christian iii died in 1559 on new year's day at koldinghus and was interred in roskilde cathedral
lines.name: English

lines.name: English

lines.name: English

lines.value: agatha christie's poirot is a british mystery drama television series that aired on itv from 8 january 1989 to 13 november 2013
lines.name: English

lines.value: david suchet stars as the eponymous detective agatha christie's fictional hercule poirot
lines.name: English

lines.value: initially produced by lwt the series was later produced by itv studios
lines.name: English

lines.value: the series also aired on visiontv in canada and on pbs and a&e in the united states
lines.name: English

lines.value: the programme ran for 13 series and 70 episodes in total each episode was adapted from a novel or short story by christie that featured poirot and consequently in each episode poirot is both the main detective in charge of the investigation of a crime usually murder and the protagonist who is at the centre of most of the episode's action
lines.name: English

lines.value: at the programme's conclusion which finished with , based on the final poirot novel every major literary work by christie that featured the title character had been adapted
lines.name: English

lines.value: clive exton in partnership with producer brian eastman adapted the pilot
lines.name: English

lines.value: together they wrote and produced the first eight series
lines.name: English

lines.value: exton and eastman left poirot after 2001 when they began work on rosemary & thyme
lines.name: English

lines.value: michele buck and damien timmer who both went on to form mammoth screen were behind the revamping of the series
lines.name: English

lines.value: the episodes aired from 2003 featured a radical shift in tone from the previous series
lines.name: English

lines.value: the humour of the earlier series was downplayed with each episode being presented as serious drama and saw the introduction of gritty elements not present in the christie stories being adapted
lines.name: English

lines.value: recurrent motifs in the additions included drug use sex abortion homosexuality and a tendency toward more visceral imagery
lines.name: English

lines.value: story changes were often made to present female characters in a more sympathetic or heroic light at odds with christie's characteristic gender neutrality
lines.name: English

lines.value: the visual style of later episodes was correspondingly different particularly an overall darker tone and austere modernist or art deco locations and decor widely used earlier in the series being largely dropped in favour of more lavish settings epitomised by the reimagining of poirot's home as a larger more lavish apartment
lines.name: English

lines.value: the series logo was redesigned the full opening title sequence had not been used since series 6 in 1996 and the main theme motif though used often was usually featured subtly and in sombre arrangements this has been described as a consequence of the novels adapted being darker and more psychologically driven
lines.name: English

lines.value: however a more upbeat string arrangement of the theme music is used for the end credits of hallowe'en party the clocks and dead man's folly
lines.name: English

lines.value: in flashback scenes later episodes also made extensive use of fisheye lens distorted colours and other visual effects
lines.name: English

lines.value: series 9 12 lack hugh fraser phillip jackson and pauline moran who had appeared in the previous series excepting series 4 where moran is absent
lines.name: English

lines.value: series 10 2006 introduced zoe wanamaker as the eccentric crime novelist ariadne oliver and david yelland as poirot's dependable valet george - a character that had been introduced in the early poirot novels but was left out of the early adaptations in order to develop the character of miss lemon
lines.name: English

lines.value: the introduction of wanamaker and yelland's characters and the absence of the other characters is generally consistent with the stories on which the scripts were based
lines.name: English

lines.value: hugh fraser and david yelland returned for two episodes of the final series the big four and curtain with phillip jackson and pauline moran returning for the adaptation of the big four
lines.name: English

lines.value: zoe wanamaker also returned for the adaptations of elephants can remember and dead man's folly
lines.name: English

lines.value: clive exton adapted seven novels and fourteen short stories for the series including the abc murders and more controversially the murder of roger ackroyd which received mixed reviews from critics
lines.name: English

lines.value: anthony horowitz was another prolific writer for the series adapting three novels and nine short stories while nick dear adapted six novels
lines.name: English

lines.value: comedian and novelist mark gatiss has written three episodes and also guest starred in the series as have peter flannery and kevin elyot
lines.name: English

lines.value: ian hallard who co wrote the screenplay for the big four with his partner mark gatiss appears in the episode and also hallowe'en party which was scripted by mark gatiss alone
lines.name: English

lines.value: florin court in charterhouse square london was used as poirot's fictional london residence whitehaven mansions
lines.name: English

lines.value: the final episode to be filmed was dead man's folly in june 2013 on the greenway estate which was agatha christie's home broadcast on 30 october 2013
lines.name: English

lines.value: most of the locations and buildings where the episodes were shot were given fictional names
lines.name: English

lines.value: suchet was recommended for the part by christie's family who had seen him appear as blott in the tv adaptation of tom sharpe's blott on the landscape
lines.name: English

lines.value: suchet a method actor said that he prepared for the part by reading all the poirot novels and every short story and copying out every piece of description about the character
lines.name: English

lines.value: suchet told strand magazine what i did was i had my file on one side of me and a pile of stories on the other side and day after day week after week i ploughed through most of agatha christie's novels about hercule poirot and wrote down characteristics until i had a file full of documentation of the character
lines.name: English

lines.value: and then it was my business not only to know what he was like but to gradually become him
lines.name: English

lines.value: i had to become him before we started shooting during the filming of the first series suchet almost left the production during an argument with a director insisting that poirot's odd mannerisms in this case putting a handkerchief down before sitting on a park bench be featured he later said there's no question [poirot's] obsessive compulsive
lines.name: English

lines.value: according to many critics and enthusiasts suchet's characterisation is considered to be the most accurate interpretation of all the actors who have played poirot and the closest to the character in the books
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2013 suchet revealed that christie's daughter rosalind hicks had told him she was sure christie would have approved of his performance
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2007 suchet spoke of his desire to film the remaining stories in the canon and hoped to achieve this before his 65th birthday in may 2011
lines.name: English

lines.value: despite speculation of cancellation early in 2011 it was announced on 14 november 2011 that the remaining books would be adapted into a thirteenth series to be filmed in 2012
lines.name: English

lines.value: the remaining books were finally adapted in 2013 into 5 episodes from which curtain aired last on 13 november 2013

lines.value: the eurovision song contest 1975 was the 20th edition of the contest hosted by sr and held in stockholm sweden

lines.value: each country would be represented by a jury of 11 members at least half of whom had to be under the age of 26

lines.value: each jury member had to award every song a mark of between 1 and 5 points but could not vote for their own nation's entry

lines.value: the votes were cast immediately after the song was performed and collected by the adjudicator straight away

lines.value: after the last song was performed the jury secretary added up all the votes cast and awarded 12 points to the song with the highest score 10 to the second highest score then 8 to the third 7 to the fourth 6 to the fifth and so forth down to 1 point for the song ranked 10th

lines.value: barkerville was the main town of the cariboo gold rush in british columbia canada and is preserved as a historic town
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is located on the north slope of the cariboo plateau near the cariboo mountains east of quesnel
lines.name: English

lines.value: bc highway 26 which follows the route of the cariboo wagon road the original access to barkerville goes through it
lines.name: English

lines.value: barkerville is situated on the western edge of the cariboo mountains in british columbia
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was named after billy barker from cambridgeshire england who was among those who first struck gold at the location in 1861
lines.name: English

lines.value: his claim was the richest and the most famous
lines.name: English

lines.value: barkerville was built up almost overnight and was a case of growth via word of mouth
lines.name: English

lines.value: it grew as fast as word of barker's strike spread
lines.name: English

lines.value: his claim would eventually yield 37500 ounces 1065 kg/2350 lb of gold
lines.name: English

lines.value: before the construction of the cariboo wagon road people hauled their own supplies to barkerville either on their backs or in a pack train
lines.name: English

lines.value: because supplies were scarce the prices of even the most everyday items were extremely high
lines.name: English

lines.value: high prices for goods in barkerville did not ease up until the cariboo road had been finished when goods could be transported by huge freight wagons
lines.name: English

lines.value: soon movers of freight boasted that they could pack and carry a set of champagne glasses without any breakage for a price of course
lines.name: English

lines.value: more women came to barkerville after the construction of the cariboo road
lines.name: English

lines.value: cattle were driven north up the okanagan valley via what is now highway 97 into canada to provide meat for the miners and residents of barkerville
lines.name: English

lines.value: at first the town consisted only of makeshift cabins and tents
lines.name: English

lines.value: by the mid 1860s however barkerville had a population of approximately 5000 3000 of them were chinese operated by kwong lee company of victoria
lines.name: English

lines.value: even though its population was transient and largely dependent on mining barkerville was becoming more of a real community
lines.name: English

lines.value: it had several general stores and boarding houses a drugstore that also sold newspapers and cigars a barbershop that cut women's as well as men's hair the wake up jake restaurant and coffee salon a theatre the theatre royal and a literary society the cariboo literary society
lines.name: English

lines.value: horse racing and prize fighting were common entertainments
lines.name: English

lines.value: among the so called sober set church services were extremely well attended
lines.name: English

lines.value: the general stores were the most profitable of the merchants
lines.name: English

lines.value: as they had the only source of food the store owners could increase the price of foods and supplies
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the height of the gold rush the stores sold flour for as high as $1.25 per pound
lines.name: English

lines.value: beans meat and dried fruit were sold for a dollar a pound
lines.name: English

lines.value: but as the gold rush ended the stores went bankrupt and finally out of business
lines.name: English

lines.value: people of chinese descent were an important part of barkerville life for almost a hundred years
lines.name: English

lines.value: they established a number of businesses including the kwong lee company a general store that sold groceries clothing hardware and mining tools
lines.name: English

lines.value: the company had stores in other parts of british columbia but the barkerville store was one of the most impressive in town
lines.name: English

lines.value: the chinese community also built cabins for chinese miners who saved money by sharing four or five to a cabin and tai ping the peace room the equivalent of a modern nursing home
lines.name: English

lines.value: chinese benevolent associations provided social services to the chinese community and also resolved disputes within the chinese community without the use of bc courts
lines.name: English

lines.value: on september 16 1868 barkerville was destroyed by a fire that spread quickly through the wooden buildings
lines.name: English

lines.value: rebuilding began immediately and at an impressive pace
lines.name: English

lines.value: within six weeks ninety buildings had been rebuilt
lines.name: English

lines.value: boardwalks were improved and the narrow and winding main street was widened and straightened
lines.name: English

lines.value: by 1880 there were enough children in the area to build the barkerville school
lines.name: English

lines.value: it had thirteen pupils and one piece of school equipment a chalkboard
lines.name: English

lines.value: even so barkerville's population was declining by the end of the 19th century and it eventually had only a few people resident
lines.name: English

lines.value: it had a revival in the 1930s when the great depression caused widespread unemployment and the price of gold skyrocketed
lines.name: English

lines.value: but as the depression turned for the better barkerville declined to a very small village
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1957 the government of british columbia decided that the town should be restored and operated as a tourist attraction
lines.name: English

lines.value: today barkerville appears as it did in its heyday and is referred to as barkerville historic town
lines.name: English

lines.value: the history of each building has been researched and documented
lines.name: English

lines.value: no residents remain they were either bought out or moved to new barkerville during the restoration of the site
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2008 barkerville's chee kung tong building was designated a national historic sites of canada
lines.name: English

lines.value: the two storey board and batten structure was completed in 1877 and originally used by the chee kung tong organization a benevolent association for recent arrivals
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is representative of the community building among immigrant chinese labourers and merchants in new settlements throughout canada
lines.name: English

lines.value: barkerville has a subarctic climate koppen climate classification dfc resulting in long cold and snowy winters accompanied by short and cool summers due to its high altitude
lines.name: English

lines.value: hitchin () is a market town in the north hertfordshire district in hertfordshire england with an estimated population of 33350
lines.name: English

lines.value: hitchin is first noted as the central place of the hicce people a tribe holding 300 hides of land as mentioned in a 7th-century document the tribal hidage
lines.name: English

lines.value: hicce or hicca may mean the people of the horse
lines.name: English

lines.value: the tribal name is old english and derives from the middle anglian people
lines.name: English

lines.value: it has been suggested that hitchin was the location of clofeshoh the place chosen in 673 by theodore of tarsus the archbishop of canterbury during the synod of hertford the first meeting of representatives of the fledgling christian churches of anglo saxon england to hold annual synods of the churches as theodore attempted to consolidate and centralise christianity in england
lines.name: English

lines.value: by 1086 hitchin is described as a royal manor in domesday book the feudal services of avera and inward usually found in the eastern counties especially cambridgeshire and hertfordshire were due from the sokemen but the manor of hitchin was unique in levying inward
lines.name: English

lines.value: evidence has been found to suggest that the town was once provided with an earthen bank and ditch fortification probably in the early tenth century but this did not last
lines.name: English

lines.value: the modern spelling hitching first appears in 1618 in the hertfordshire feet of fines
lines.name: English

lines.value: the name of the town also is associated with the small river that runs through the town most picturesquely in front of the east end of st mary's church the town's parish church
lines.name: English

lines.value: the river is noted on maps as the river hiz
lines.name: English

lines.value: contrary to how most people now pronounce the name that is to say as spelt the z is an abbreviated character for a tch sound in the domesday book as in the name of the town
lines.name: English

lines.value: it would have been pronounced river hitch
lines.name: English

lines.value: the hicca way is an eight mile walking route along the river hiz valley believed to have been used for trade between the danes and english in the anglo saxon age
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is also likely that hitch wood which lies some half a dozen miles south of the town also derives its name from the hicce tribe who gave their name to hitchin
lines.name: English

lines.value: hitchin is notable for st mary's church which is remarkably large for a town of its size
lines.name: English

lines.value: the size of the church is evidence of how hitchin prospered from the wool trade
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is the largest parish church in hertfordshire
lines.name: English

lines.value: most of the church dates from the 15th century with its tower dating from around 1190
lines.name: English

lines.value: during the laying of a new floor in the church in 1911 foundations of a more ancient church building were found
lines.name: English

lines.value: in form they appear to be a basilican church of a 7th-century type with a later enlarged chancel and transepts perhaps added in the 10th century
lines.name: English

lines.value: this makes the church older than the story not recorded before the 15th century that the church was founded by offa king of mercia 757-796
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1697 hitchin and the nearby village of offley were subject to what is thought to have been the most severe hailstorm in recorded british history
lines.name: English

lines.value: hailstones over 4 inches in diameter were reported the town flourished on the wool trade and located near the icknield way and by the 17th century hitchin was a staging post for coaches coming from london
lines.name: English

lines.value: by the middle of the 19th century the railway had arrived and with it a new way of life for hitchin
lines.name: English

lines.value: the corn exchange was built in the market place and within a short time hitchin established itself as a major centre for grain trading
lines.name: English

lines.value: the latter half of the 20th century has also brought great changes in communication to hitchin
lines.name: English

lines.value: motorways have shortened the journey time and brought luton a few miles away on the m1 and the a1 m even closer
lines.name: English

lines.value: by the close of the 20th century hitchin had become a satellite dormitory town for london
lines.name: English

lines.value: hitchin also developed a fairly strong sikh community based around the walsworth area
lines.name: English

lines.value: during the medieval period both a priory newbigging now known as the biggin and a friary now known as hitchin priory were established both of which closed during henry viii's dissolution of the monasteries
lines.name: English

lines.value: they were never reformed although the biggin was for many years used as almshouses
lines.name: English

lines.value: the british schools museum in hitchin is home to the world's only known complete lancasterian schoolroom which was built in 1837 to teach boys by the lancasterian method peer tutoring
lines.name: English

lines.value: girton college a pioneer in women's education was established on 16 october 1869 under the name of college for women at benslow house in hitchin which was considered to be a convenient distance from cambridge and london
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was thought to be less risky and less controversial to locate the college away from cambridge in the beginning
lines.name: English

lines.value: the college moved to cambridge a few years later and adopted its present name girton college
lines.name: English

lines.value: hitchin is in the local government district of north hertfordshire which was formed in 1974 by the amalgamation of rural and urban councils
lines.name: English

lines.value: there is now no town council in hitchin
lines.name: English

lines.value: residents elect 13 members to the north hertfordshire district council
lines.name: English

lines.value: there are five electoral wards in hitchin bearton highbury oughton priory and walsworth

lines.value: wimax worldwide interoperability for microwave access is a family of wireless communication standards based on the ieee 802.16 set of standards which provide multiple physical layer phy and media access control mac options

lines.value: the name wimax was created by the wimax forum which was formed in june 2001 to promote conformity and interoperability of the standard including the definition of predefined system profiles for commercial vendors

lines.value: the forum describes wimax as a standards based technology enabling the delivery of last mile wireless broadband access as an alternative to cable and dsl

lines.value: wimax refers to interoperable implementations of the ieee 802.16 family of wireless networks standards ratified by the wimax forum
lines.name: English

lines.value: similarly wi fi refers to interoperable implementations of the ieee 802.11 wireless lan standards certified by the wi fi alliance wimax forum certification allows vendors to sell fixed or mobile products as wimax certified thus ensuring a level of interoperability with other certified products as long as they fit the same profile

lines.value: the original ieee 802.16 standard now called fixed wimax was published in 2001

lines.value: wimax adopted some of its technology from wibro a service marketed in korea

lines.value: mobile wimax originally based on 802.16e-2005 is the revision that was deployed in many countries and is the basis for future revisions such as 802.16m-2011

lines.value: wimax is sometimes referred to as wi fi on steroids and can be used for a number of applications including broadband connections cellular backhaul hotspots etc it is similar to long range wi fi but it can enable usage at much greater distances

lines.value: the bandwidth and range of wimax make it suitable for the following potential applications

lines.value: wimax can provide at home or mobile internet access across whole cities or countries

lines.value: in many cases this has resulted in competition in markets which typically only had access through an existing incumbent dsl or similar operator

lines.value: additionally given the relatively low costs associated with the deployment of a wimax network in comparison with 3g hsdpa xdsl hfc or fttx it is now economically viable to provide last mile broadband internet access in remote locations
lines.name: English

lines.value: mobile wimax was a replacement candidate for cellular phone technologies such as gsm and cdma or can be used as an overlay to increase capacity
lines.name: English

lines.value: fixed wimax is also considered as a wireless backhaul technology for 2g 3g and 4g networks in both developed and developing nations
lines.name: English

lines.value: in north america backhaul for urban operations is typically provided via one or more copper wire line connections whereas remote cellular operations are sometimes backhauled via satellite

lines.value: in other regions urban and rural backhaul is usually provided by microwave links

lines.value: the exception to this is where the network is operated by an incumbent with ready access to the copper network wimax has more substantial backhaul bandwidth requirements than legacy cellular applications

lines.value: consequently the use of wireless microwave backhaul is on the rise in north america and existing microwave backhaul links in all regions are being upgraded

lines.value: capacities of between 34 mbit s and 1 gbit s are routinely being deployed with latencies in the order of 1 ms.in many cases operators are aggregating sites using wireless technology and then presenting traffic on to fiber networks where convenient

lines.value: wimax in this application competes with microwave radio e line and simple extension of the fiber network itself

lines.value: as a standard intended to satisfy needs of next generation data networks 4g wimax is distinguished by its dynamic burst algorithm modulation adaptive to the physical environment the rf signal travels through

lines.value: modulation is chosen to be more spectrally efficient more bits per ofdm/sofdma symbol

lines.value: that is when the bursts have a high signal strength and a high carrier to noise plus interference ratio cinr they can be more easily decoded using digital signal processing dsp

lines.value: in contrast operating in less favorable environments for rf communication the system automatically steps down to a more robust mode burst profile which means fewer bits per ofdm/sofdma symbol with the advantage that power per bit is higher and therefore simpler accurate signal processing can be performed

lines.value: the software utility cron is a time based job scheduler in unix like computer operating systems
lines.name: English

lines.value: people who set up and maintain software environments use cron to schedule jobs commands or shell scripts to run periodically at fixed times dates or intervals
lines.name: English

lines.value: it typically automates system maintenance or administration though its general purpose nature makes it useful for things like downloading files from the internet and downloading email at regular intervals
lines.name: English

lines.value: the origin of the name cron is from the greek word for time xpovos chronos
lines.name: English

lines.value: cron is most suitable for scheduling repetitive tasks
lines.name: English

lines.value: scheduling one time tasks is often more easily accomplished using the associated at utility
lines.name: English

lines.value: cron is driven by a crontab cron table file a configuration file that specifies shell commands to run periodically on a given schedule
lines.name: English

lines.value: the crontab files are stored where the lists of jobs and other instructions to the cron daemon are kept
lines.name: English

lines.value: users can have their own individual crontab files and often there is a system wide crontab file usually in ) that only system administrators can edit
lines.name: English

lines.value: each line of a crontab file represents a job and looks like this while normally the job is executed when the time date specification fields all match the current time and date there is one exception if both day of month field 3 and day of week field 5 are restricted not * then one or both must match the current day
lines.name: English

lines.value: for example the following clears the apache error log at one minute past midnight 00:01 every day assuming that the default shell for the cron user is bourne shell compliant implementations such as the popular 4th bsd edition written by paul vixie and included in many linux distributions add a sixth field an account username that runs the specified job subject to user existence and permissions
lines.name: English

lines.value: this is allowed only in the system crontabs not in others which are each assigned to a single user to configure
lines.name: English

lines.value: the sixth field is alternatively sometimes used for year instead of an account username the nncron daemon for windows does this

lines.value: in the august 1977 issue of the communications of the acm w r franta and kurt maly published an article entitled an efficient data structure for the simulation event set describing an event queue data structure for discrete event driven simulation systems that demonstrated performance superior to that of commonly used simple linked list algorithms good behavior given non uniform time distributions and worst case complexity n being the number of events in the queue
