lines.value: paulina luisi 1875-1945 was a leader of the feminist movement in the country of uruguay
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1909 she became the first uruguayan woman to earn a medical degree in uruguay
lines.name: English

lines.value: she was highly respected
lines.name: English

lines.value: she represented uruguay in international women's conferences and traveled throughout europe
lines.name: English

lines.value: she voiced her opinion on women's rights and in 1919 paulina started the force for women's rights in uruguay
lines.name: English

lines.value: by 1922 the pan american conference of women named paulina luisi an honorary vice president of the meeting and she continued to be an activist until uruguay gave women the right to vote
lines.name: English

lines.value: paulina luisi was born in argentina in 1875
lines.name: English

lines.value: her mother maria teresa josefina janicki was of polish descent and her father angel luisi was believed to have come from an italian ancestry
lines.name: English

lines.value: paulina luisi received a bachelor's degree in 1899 and later was the first female physician and surgeon that graduated from the medicine school of the universidad de la republica university of uruguay 1908
lines.name: English

lines.value: her sister clotilde luisi was the first uruguayan woman to study at the faculty of law of the university of the republic
lines.name: English

lines.value: she was not only a physician but also a teacher and the primary editor of the magazine accion femenina
lines.name: English

lines.value: throughout her career she held various positions and achieved more than any woman in her country had
lines.name: English

lines.value: the primary figures that luisi drew inspiration from and who provided her with undivided support were her parents angel and maria
lines.name: English

lines.value: her mother maria encouraged her daughter to pursue her dreams despite the social stigma placed on women at the time
lines.name: English

lines.value: her father angel an educator and socialist instilled in her an uncontainable desire for justice and liberty thus throughout her life luisi recognized herself as a socialist and her attention was mainly focused on getting people to practice moral unity
lines.name: English

lines.value: by this she meant that all people should be aware of their responsibilities in a society
lines.name: English

lines.value: in her case the main purpose of moral unity was to restrain the practice of prostitution to check the spread of venereal disease to protect the future of the human race and to elevate motherhood from the realm of lust to that of progenitor and guardian of the species
lines.name: English

lines.value: josephine butler a famous 19th-century english moral reformer had powerful influence on luisi as well
lines.name: English

lines.value: her fight against the contagious disease act of 1864 and her founding of the international abolitionist federation in geneva switzerland to curb the white slave trade served as a continual source of inspiration for luisi
lines.name: English

lines.value: luisi's feminist ideas were primarily built upon other movements occurring around the 20th century
lines.name: English

lines.value: while luisi was still a student argentine liberal feminist petrona eyle wrote to her in her capacity as president of the universitarias argentinas argentine association of university women affiliated with the american association of university women or aauw recruiting her to join the organization
lines.name: English

lines.value: in a letter dated 1 may 1907 eyle encouraged luisi and her female colleagues in the university to form a uruguayan branch of the universitarias stating that although there aren't many of you now you will always be the nucleus around which others will come together
lines.name: English

lines.value: it appears that luisi and others accepted this invitation and joined with their argentine counterparts in 1907
lines.name: English

lines.value: important also to luisi's insertion into pan american liberal feminist networks and in her propulsion to the leadership of still germinating uruguayan liberal feminism was her participation in the women's congress congreso femenino held in buenos aires in 1910
lines.name: English

lines.value: there she became acquainted with prominent argentine feminists such as alicia moreau de justo and cecilia gierson organized by the universitarias the conference brought together more than 200 women representing argentina uruguay peru paraguay and chile
lines.name: English

lines.value: it seems likely that it was at this conference that luisi first came into contact with many of the leaders or soon to be leaders of liberal feminism in south america and where she would establish her contacts and friendships what would endure for decades afterwards
lines.name: English

lines.value: trips to europe brought her into contact with women such as avril saint croix president of the moral unity committee of the international council of women and jules siegfried president of the french national council of women
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1917 luisi published a definition of feminism in the magazine accion femenina stating ...demonstrating that woman is something more than material created to serve and obey man like a slave that she is more than a machine to produce children and care for the home that women have feelings and intellect that it is their mission to perpetuate the species and this must be done with more than the entrails and the breasts it must be done with a mind and a heart prepared to be a mother and an educator that she must be the man's partner and counselor not his slave
lines.name: English

lines.value: luisi was the first latin american woman that participated in the league of nations as a government representative
lines.name: English

lines.name: English

lines.name: English

lines.value: besides being actively involved in government luisi was also involved in the classroom
lines.name: English

lines.value: she worked as a teacher at the teacher's training college for women and as an advocate reaching out for social hygiene related to the teaching profession
lines.name: English

lines.value: her lectures and arguments were specifically designed to introduce prophylaxis as a subject within the teachers training syllabus
lines.name: English

lines.value: a controversial aspect of luisi's moral reform platform was obligatory sex health education programs in the public school system
lines.name: English

lines.value: she suggested having these programs first introduced in the primary schools and then continuing on to the secondary level
lines.name: English

lines.value: she defined sex education as the pedagogic tool to teach the individual to subject sexual drives to the will of an instructed conscientious and responsible intellect
lines.name: English

lines.value: classes in sex education would emphasize the need for will power and self discipline regular moderate physical exercise to burn up sexual energy and the desirability of avoiding sexually stimulating entertainments
lines.name: English

lines.value: as opposed to sex education health education classes would focus more on the scientific aspects of reproduction of the species natural history anatomy personal hygiene and the prevention of venereal diseases
lines.name: English

lines.value: due to these suggestions luisi was called an anarchist and a revolutionary
lines.name: English

lines.value: she was also accused of wanting to teach students how to become prostitutes
lines.name: English

lines.value: a point mutation is a genetic mutation where a single nucleotide base is changed inserted or deleted from a sequence of dna or rna
lines.name: English

lines.value: point mutations have a variety of effects on the downstream protein product consequences that are moderately predictable based upon the specifics of the mutation
lines.name: English

lines.value: these consequences can range from benign e.g synonymous mutations to catastrophic e.g frameshift mutations with regard to protein production composition and function
lines.name: English

lines.value: point mutation is a random snp single-nucleotide polymorphism mutation in the deoxyribonucleic acid dna that occurs at one point
lines.name: English

lines.value: point mutations usually take place during dna replication
lines.name: English

lines.value: dna replication occurs when one double stranded dna molecule creates two single strands of dna each of which is a template for the creation of the complementary strand
lines.name: English

lines.value: a single point mutation can change the whole dna sequence
lines.name: English

lines.value: changing one purine or pyrimidine may change the amino acid that the nucleotides code for
lines.name: English

lines.value: point mutations may arise from spontaneous mutations that occur during dna replication
lines.name: English

lines.value: the rate of mutation may be increased by mutagens
lines.name: English

lines.value: mutagens can be physical such as radiation from uv rays x rays or extreme heat or chemical molecules that misplace base pairs or disrupt the helical shape of dna
lines.name: English

lines.value: mutagens associated with cancers are often studied to learn about cancer and its prevention
lines.name: English

lines.value: there are multiple ways for point mutations to occur
lines.name: English

lines.value: first ultraviolet uv light and higher frequency light are capable of ionizing electrons which in turn can affect dna
lines.name: English

lines.value: reactive oxygen molecules with free radicals which are a byproduct of cellular metabolism can also be very harmful to dna
lines.name: English

lines.value: these reactants can lead to both single stranded dna breaks and double stranded dna breaks
lines.name: English

lines.value: third bonds in dna eventually degrade which creates another problem to keep the integrity of dna to a high standard
lines.name: English

lines.value: there can also be replication errors that lead to substitution insertion or deletion mutations
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was previously believed that these mutations happened completely by chance with no regard for their effects on the organisms
lines.name: English

lines.value: recently there have been studies suggesting that these mutations occur in response to environmental challenges
lines.name: English

lines.value: that is to say they are more likely to occur when they are advantageous to the organism rather than when they are neutral or disadvantageous
lines.name: English

lines.value: when cells were deprived of a certain amino acid tryptophan for prolonged periods of time point mutations in trp operon reverted to tryptophan leading to an advantageous result more frequently than under normal conditions when the mutations were neutral
lines.name: English

lines.value: in addition the tryptophan mutation rate was unaffected when the cells were deprived of another amino acid cysteine further suggesting that the mutation rate was specific to situations in which the mutation was advantageous
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1959 ernst freese coined the terms transitions or transversions to categorize different types of point mutations
lines.name: English

lines.value: transitions are replacement of a purine base with another purine or replacement of a pyrimidine with another pyrimidine
lines.name: English

lines.value: transversions are replacement of a purine with a pyrimidine or vice versa
lines.name: English

lines.value: there is a systematic difference in mutation rates for transitions alpha and transversions beta
lines.name: English

lines.value: transition mutations are about ten times more common than transversions
lines.name: English

lines.value: nonsense mutations include stop gain and start loss
lines.name: English

lines.value: stop gain is a mutation that results in a premature termination codon a stop was gained which signals the end of translation
lines.name: English

lines.value: this interruption causes the protein to be abnormally shortened
lines.name: English

lines.value: the number of amino acids lost mediates the impact on the protein's functionality and whether it will function whatsoever
lines.name: English

lines.value: stop loss is a mutation in the original termination codon a stop was lost resulting in abnormal extension of a protein's carboxyl terminus
lines.name: English

lines.value: start gain creates a aug start codon upstream of the original start site
lines.name: English

lines.value: if the new aug is near the original start site in frame within the processed transcript and downstream to a ribosomal binding site it can be used to initiate translation
lines.name: English

lines.value: the likely effect is additional amino acids added to the amino terminus of the original protein
lines.name: English

lines.value: frame shift mutations are also possible in start gain mutations but typically do not affect translation of the original protein
lines.name: English

lines.value: start loss is a point mutation in a transcript's aug start codon resulting in the reduction or elimination of protein production
lines.name: English

lines.value: missense mutations code for a different amino acid
lines.name: English

lines.value: a missense mutation changes a codon so that a different protein is created a non synonymous change
lines.name: English

lines.value: conservative mutations result in an amino acid change
lines.name: English

lines.value: however the properties of the amino acid remain the same e.g hydrophobic hydrophilic etc
lines.name: English

lines.value: at times a change to one amino acid in the protein is not detrimental to the organism as a whole
lines.name: English

lines.value: most proteins can withstand one or two point mutations before their function changes

lines.value: non conservative mutations result in an amino acid change that has different properties than the wild type
lines.name: English

lines.value: the protein may lose its function which can result in a disease in the organism

lines.value: in molecular biology repeatinduced point mutation or rip is a process by which dna accumulates g:c to a:t transition mutations

lines.value: genomic evidence indicates that rip occurs or has occurred in a variety of fungi while experimental evidence indicates that rip is active in neurospora crassa podospora anserina magnaporthe grisea leptosphaeria maculans gibberella zeae and nectria haematococca

lines.value: rip occurs during the sexual stage in haploid nuclei after fertilization but prior to meiotic dna replication

lines.value: in neurospora crassa repeat sequences of at least 400 base pairs in length are vulnerable to rip

lines.value: repeats with as low as 80% nucleotide identity may also be subject to rip

lines.value: though the exact mechanism of repeat recognition and mutagenesis are poorly understood rip results in repeated sequences undergoing multiple transition mutations

lines.value: the rip mutations do not seem to be limited to repeated sequences

lines.value: indeed for example in the phytopathogenic fungus l

lines.value: maculans rip mutations are found in single copy regions adjacent to the repeated elements

lines.value: these regions are either non coding regions or genes encoding small secreted proteins including avirulence genes

lines.value: the degree of rip within these single copy regions was proportional to their proximity to repetitive elements

lines.value: rep and kistler have speculated that the presence of highly repetitive regions containing transposons may promote mutation of resident effector genes
lines.name: English

lines.value: so the presence of effector genes within such regions is suggested to promote their adaptation and diversification when exposed to strong selection pressure

lines.value: as rip mutation is traditionally observed to be restricted to repetitive regions and not single copy regions fudal et al suggested that leakage of rip mutation might occur within a relatively short distance of a rip affected repeat

lines.value: indeed this has been reported in n

lines.value: crassa whereby leakage of rip was detected in single copy sequences at least 930 bp from the boundary of neighbouring duplicated sequences

lines.value: to elucidate the mechanism of detection of repeated sequences leading to rip may allow to understand how the flanking sequences may also be affected

lines.value: rip causes g:c to a:t transition mutations within repeats however the mechanism that detects the repeated sequences is unknown

lines.value: rid is the only known protein essential for rip

lines.value: it is a dna methyltransferease like protein that when mutated or knocked out results in loss of rip

lines.value: hermann fol continued hertwig's research by testing the effects of injecting several spermatozoa into an egg and found that the process did not work with more than one spermatozoon

lines.value: the study of cells was an increasingly popular topic in this time period

lines.value: sydney hospital is a major hospital in australia located on macquarie street in the sydney central business district

lines.value: it is the oldest hospital in australia dating back to 1788 and has been at its current location since 1811

lines.value: currently the hospital comprises 113 inpatient beds

lines.value: specialist services attract patients from all over new south wales
lines.name: English

lines.value: it specialises in ophthalmology and hand surgery and is a referral hospital for patients requiring these services

lines.value: it also houses a rudimentary 6-bed emergency department
lines.name: English

lines.value: sydney hospital became a teaching hospital of the university of sydney in 1909

lines.value: sydney hospital is associated with sydney medical school of the university of sydney through the discipline of clinical ophthalmology and eye health and save sight institute

lines.value: many of the 736 convicts who survived the voyage of the first fleet from portsmouth england arrived suffering from dysentery smallpox scurvy and typhoid
lines.name: English

lines.value: soon after landing governor phillip and surgeon general john white established a tent hospital along what is now george street in the rocks to care for the worst cases
lines.name: English

lines.value: subsequent convict boatloads had even higher rates of death and disease
lines.name: English

lines.value: a portable hospital which was prefabricated in england from wood and copper arrived in sydney with the second fleet in 1790
lines.name: English

lines.value: present day nurses walk in the rocks cuts across where the site of the early hospital once was
lines.name: English

lines.value: john white was surgeon general at sydney cove between 1788 and 1794
lines.name: English

lines.value: upon his arrival in the colony of new south wales at the beginning of 1810 governor macquarie discovered that the sydney cove's hospital was an affair of tents and temporary buildings
lines.name: English

lines.value: macquarie set aside land on the western edge of the government domain for a new hospital and created a new road - macquarie street - to provide access to it
lines.name: English

lines.value: plans were drawn up but the british government refused to provide funds to build the hospital
lines.name: English

lines.value: consequently macquarie entered into a contract with a consortium of businessmen–garnham blaxcell alexander riley and later d'arcy wentworth–to erect the new hospital
lines.name: English

lines.value: they were to receive convict labour and supplies and a monopoly on rum imports from which they expected to recoup the cost of the building and gain considerable profits
lines.name: English

lines.value: the contract allowed them to import 45000 later increased to 60000 gallons of rum to sell to colonists and was signed on 6 november 1810
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the event the hospital did not turn out to be very profitable for the contractors
lines.name: English

lines.value: convict patients were transferred to governor macquarie's new hospital in 1816
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is unclear who prepared the design for the three old colonial georgian buildings comprising the sydney hospital complex but there were apparently many involved with its construction
lines.name: English

lines.value: there is speculation that both governor macquarie and john o'hearen contributed to the design
lines.name: English

lines.value: john o'hearen is probably the stronger contender for being the building's designer for he not only defended the methods of its construction against critics but also signed himself as architect in related correspondence
lines.name: English

lines.value: as the hospital was nearing completion in 1815 the now famous convict architect francis greenway was asked to report on the quality of the work
lines.name: English

lines.value: he condemned it claiming that it must soon fall into ruin
lines.name: English

lines.value: short cuts had been taken with the construction and there were weak joints in the structural beams rotting stonework feeble foundations and dry rot in the timbers
lines.name: English

lines.value: macquarie ordered the contractors to remedy these defects but by 1820 the southern wing was deemed particularly unsafe with reports that some of it had collapsed and had to be rebuilt
lines.name: English

lines.value: around this time greenway was commissioned to undertake repairs to both the wings of the hospital including alterations to the roof of the southern wing and the rearrangement of its internal spaces
lines.name: English

lines.value: more substantial repairs were carried out on the southern wing in 1826
lines.name: English

lines.value: many defects present from the original construction remained hidden away until the extensive restoration of the 1980s
lines.name: English

lines.value: the scale of the hospital was greater than that which could be sustained by sydney at that time
lines.name: English

lines.value: the new hospital had a large central building which was the main hospital and two smaller wings which were quarters for the surgeons
lines.name: English

lines.value: from the start portions of the buildings were allocated for non medical purposes
lines.name: English

lines.value: during construction there was ongoing debate about the hospital's future possible use
lines.name: English

lines.value: governor macquarie was under pressure both within the colony and from lord bathurst to utilise part of the general hospital as a temporary supreme court perhaps while awaiting the construction of the greenway designed law courts opposite
lines.name: English

lines.value: macquarie capitulated and the northern wing originally designed for the principal surgeon and a portion of the central building were given over to supreme court judge jeffrey hart bent as chambers as well as for a temporary courthouse
lines.name: English

lines.value: the first surgeon to reside at the hospital's surgeons quarters was d'arcy wentworth whose other connections with the building are interesting
lines.name: English

lines.value: first he had been one of the three contractors who had built the hospital under the rum contract with macquarie and secondly his son william charles wentworth explorer and journalist became one of the most important figures in the development of parliamentary democracy in new south wales and is regarded as the father of the constitution
lines.name: English

lines.value: he is well commemorated by artworks within parliament house
lines.name: English

lines.value: on 3 january 1829 governor darling released a despatch foreshadowing the intended appropriation of the north wing for the accommodation of the legislative councils
lines.name: English

lines.value: the first meeting of the 14 member legislative council in the north wing occurred on 21 august 1829
lines.name: English

lines.value: the first legislative council stayed until 1848
lines.name: English

lines.value: during this time the surgeons continued to occupy about one third of the space
lines.name: English

lines.value: other rooms were sometimes occupied by other government officials such as the principal supervisor of convicts until 1852 when the legislature took over the entire building
lines.name: English

lines.value: when the general hospital was completed in 1816 the southern wing was used for its planned purpose as the quarters for the assistant surgeon as well as a storage facility
lines.name: English

lines.value: however from 1823 the 39th regiment and briefly the 57th regiment used some of the rooms as hospital wards
lines.name: English

lines.value: the staff office including clerical offices and a medical depot for the military occupied the southern wing until 1854
lines.name: English

lines.value: from 1836 the store master also lived there sharing the upper rooms with the assistant surgeon
lines.name: English

lines.value: there were plans for the southern wing to become a military hospital in 1840 however this did not come to fruition
lines.name: English

lines.value: colonial governments accepted a degree of responsibility for pauper patients who were not convicts
lines.name: English

lines.value: however as convict numbers declined and the emancipated and free population grew the government disengaged itself from direct responsibility for the respectable poor
lines.name: English

lines.value: meanwhile the sydney dispensary had been created in 1826 to provide outpatient care for free poor persons unable to pay for medical attendance
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was conducted on traditional charitable lines and operated from several city premises before obtaining the south wing of the rum hospital in 1845 where it remained until 1848
lines.name: English

lines.value: this change in use of the south wing required more repairs to the internal and external building fabric from 1843
lines.name: English

lines.value: at the same time the sydney dispensary expanded to serve inpatients and changed its name to the sydney infirmary and dispensary a title officially approved in 1844
lines.name: English

lines.value: convict inpatients continued to be treated in the separately managed hospital in the centre wing next door
lines.name: English

lines.value: with the dissolution of the convict hospital system the sydney infirmary and dispensary gave up the south wing in 1848 in return for permissive occupancy of the entire middle section of the rum hospital complex
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1851 the new south wales legislative council petitioned to establish a mint in sydney to take advantage of the gold discovered by edward hargreaves at ophir just outside bathurst
lines.name: English

lines.value: this proposal received royal assent in 1853
lines.name: English

lines.value: plans were drawn up for the sydney branch on a site selected at the corner of bridge and macquarie streets however it was decided to locate the mint in the southern wing of the general hospital to save time and costs
lines.name: English

lines.value: the south wing officially became the sydney branch of the royal mint in 1854
lines.name: English

lines.value: its establishment required the extensive internal remodelling of the former hospital wing for accommodation for the mint master administrative offices and receiving and storage rooms for bullion
lines.name: English

lines.value: land to the rear of the building was also developed with prefabricated industrial buildings for rolling assaying and coining imported from england and erected around a courtyard directly behind the former hospital building
lines.name: English

lines.value: the mint was shut down in 1926 when the royal melbourne mint became the mint of the commonwealth
lines.name: English

lines.value: the building has since accommodated numerous government departments and various law courts
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1982 the mint offices building opened as australia's first museum of historical decorative arts stamps and coins although the coining factory buildings at the rear continued to be used as law courts and as a workshop for the department of public works
lines.name: English

lines.value: the mint museum won both the new south wales and national museum of the year awards in 1983
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1993-5 the museum was redeveloped as the sydney mint museum focusing on the impact of the gold rush years on new south wales and the role of the mint as a coining factory
lines.name: English

lines.value: however this redeveloped museum was short lived closing in 1997
lines.name: English

lines.value: the property comprising the mint offices and courtyard was transferred to the historic houses trust in 1998

lines.value: the deteriorated centre building was demolished in 1879 and in 1880 thomas rowe won an architectural competition held to find a new design with his victorian classical revival design
lines.name: English

lines.value: rowe was heavily criticised by his peers for the practice of under quoting building costs in order to win a competition and the sydney infirmary was his

lines.value: work halted for some years after partial construction awaiting the approval of additional funds from the new south wales parliament
lines.name: English

lines.value: new south wales politician henry parkes who later became premier was concerned about the state of the sydney infirmary and dispensary and appealed for help to florence nightingale for trained nurses
lines.name: English

lines.value: consequently in march 1868 lucy osburn was sent out as lady superintendent of the infirmary and was accompanied by five trained nurses
lines.name: English

lines.value: osburn won parkes trust and began the challenging task of cleaning up the crumbling foul smelling and vermin infested infirmary
lines.name: English

lines.value: a week after their arrival they had a royal patient when the duke of edinburgh was wounded by a would be assassin at clontarf
lines.name: English

lines.value: they nursed him at government house not sydney hospital
lines.name: English

lines.value: in spite of the public acclaim this brought them lucy osburn and her staff faced much resistance in their efforts to reform the infirmary
lines.name: English

lines.value: in addition to the appalling conditions they met with hostility and opposition
lines.name: English

lines.value: the idea of gentlewomen working as hospital nurses was still novel and to many people shocking
lines.name: English

lines.value: lucy was continually obstructed by one surgeon dr alfred roberts and personally attacked in the parliament
lines.name: English

lines.value: a royal commission on public charities in 1873 condemned the sydney infirmary accusing the management committee of neglect and interfering in the duties of the nurses
lines.name: English

lines.value: osburn was vindicated and the commission praised her work toward the improvement in the standards of nursing
lines.name: English

lines.value: a number of the lucy osburn's sisters took up positions as matrons at various hospitals
lines.name: English

lines.value: by these means the nightingale teaching and standards became accepted practice in the hospital system of the colony
lines.name: English

lines.value: by the time she returned to england she had laid the foundation of modern nursing in new south wales
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1881 the infirmary's name was changed to the sydney hospital
lines.name: English

lines.value: lucy osburn left sydney in 1884 and returned to london
lines.name: English

lines.value: after some years nursing among the sick and poor in london she died of diabetes at her sister's home in harrogate on 22 december 1891
lines.name: English

lines.value: lucy osburn was described by her successor at sydney hospital miss mckay as an exceptional woman who regarded nursing as the highest employment to be entered with a spirit of devotion

lines.value: one of her common recommendations to those taking up the profession was reported as being you nurses should exist for patients not they for you

lines.value: tiefu () was a pre state xiongnu tribe during the era of sixteen kingdoms in china

lines.value: its ruins were discovered during the qing dynasty and can still be seen in present day inner mongolia

lines.value: karl kruszelnicki ( ; born 20 march 1948 often referred to as dr karl is a well known australian science communicator and populariser who is known as an author and science commentator on australian radio and television

lines.value: his mother's background was hidden from him for a long time with his mother having told him that she was swedish and a lutheran but was in fact jewish

lines.value: kruszelnicki's family emigrated to australia when he was 2 years of age

lines.value: kruszelnicki presented the first series of quantum replaced by catalyst in 1985

lines.value: as a science communicator and presenter he appears on channel 7's weekend sunrise program and on abc television

lines.value: ashley stephen hutchings mbe born 26 january 1945 is an english bassist vocalist songwriter arranger band leader writer and record producer
lines.name: English

lines.value: he was a founding member of three of the most noteworthy english folk rock bands in the history of the genre fairport convention steeleye span and the albion band
lines.name: English

lines.value: hutchings has overseen numerous other projects including records and live theatre and has collaborated on film and television projects
lines.name: English

lines.value: hutchings was born in southgate england but moved to muswell hill while still a child
lines.name: English

lines.value: as a teenager he became involved in the skiffle and blues movements and formed several groups including dr k's blues band in 1964
lines.name: English

lines.value: he met guitarist simon nicol in 1966 when they both played in the ethnic shuffle orchestra
lines.name: English

lines.value: they rehearsed on the floor above nicol's father's medical practice in a house called fairport and lent its name to the group they formed together as fairport convention in 1967 with richard thompson which soon included martin lamble judy dyble and iain matthews
lines.name: English

lines.value: hutchings played on the band's first four albums
lines.name: English

lines.value: the first three fairport convention 1968 what we did on our holidays 1969 and unhalfbricking 1969 largely consisted of american singer songwriter material and original songs in a similar style
lines.name: English

lines.value: hutchings restrained but powerful bass style is one of the characteristics of the band in this period
lines.name: English

lines.value: the focus of the band changed with the introduction of dave swarbrick into the line up who brought a virtuosity on the fiddle and a wealth of traditional tunes
lines.name: English

lines.value: this prompted hutchings to carry out research in the english folk dance & song society library at cecil sharp house which resulted in the pioneering classic liege and lief 1969 seen by many as the foundation of british folk rock
lines.name: English

lines.value: hutchings was however increasingly unhappy with the direction of the band as most members wanted to return to their older format
lines.name: English

lines.value: as a result in 1969 he left to focus on more traditional projects
lines.name: English

lines.value: hutchings new band steeleye span was formed by putting together two established folk duos tim hart and maddy prior with terry and gay woods
lines.name: English

lines.value: the woodses departed the band shortly after the release of their debut album hark
lines.name: English

lines.value: the village wait 1970 and were replaced by singer guitarist martin carthy and fiddler peter knight
lines.name: English

lines.value: the resulting line up toured small concert venues and recorded two highly regarded albums please to see the king 1971 and ten man mop or mr reservoir butler rides again 1972 both providing electric versions of traditional songs
lines.name: English

lines.value: the bringing in of manager jo lustig who pushed for a more commercial sound was probably what prompted the more traditionally minded carthy and hutchings to leave the band which continued with changes of line up and achieved considerable mainstream success
lines.name: English

lines.value: by this point the ever active hutchings already had other projects underway
lines.name: English

lines.value: he had gathered together the first incarnation of what has been the major outlet for his work the albion country band to provide backing for his then wife shirley collins on her solo collection no roses 1971
lines.name: English

lines.value: some of these personnel co operated with him for the album morris on 1972 an affectionate electric tribute to morris dancing and others joined him in his next project the etchingham steam band from 1974 6
lines.name: English

lines.value: when this dissolved without releasing a record he returned to the albion band in 1976 which with many bewildering line up changes continued to record and tour regularly until 2002
lines.name: English

lines.value: outside of the albion band hutchings has been a frequent guest on the albums of a wide variety of folk artists
lines.name: English

lines.value: he has also continued to pursue a diversity of projects some alone and some with groupings of more or less stability and continuity
lines.name: English

lines.value: the morris on project has spawned several sequels across his career son of morris on 1976 grandson of morris on 2002 and great grandson of morris on 2004
lines.name: English

lines.value: there have also been several other dance projects including with john kirkpatrick and other artists the compleat dancing master 1974 rattlebone & ploughjack 1976 and kicking up the sawdust 1977
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1984 hutchings wrote and toured with a one man show about folk song collector cecil sharp which resulted in the album an hour with cecil sharp and ashley hutchings 1986
lines.name: English

lines.value: from this point he often combined writing and narration with his music as in by gloucester docks i sat down and wept a love story 1987 which was produced as a live show and album in 1990
lines.name: English

lines.value: he produced an album of spoken word material as a word in your ear 1991 another themed album combining music and narration with judy dunlop as sway with me 1991
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the late 1980s he toured with the ashley hutchings all stars leading to a live album as you like it 1988
lines.name: English

lines.value: with phil beer and chris while he provided the sound track for the tv series the ridge riders which resulted in an album ridgeriders songs of the southern english landscape htd 1995 a short tour and another live album ridgeriders in concert talking elephant 1996
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the 1990s he returned to his own musical roots of skiffle and rock and roll touring and recording with the ashley hutchings big beat combo which resulted in the album twanging and a tradding 1994
lines.name: English

lines.value: he also returned to his interest in dance in addition to continuing the morris on project he formed the ashley hutchings dance band to produce a batter pudding for john keats 1996
lines.name: English

lines.value: other projects include with malcolm rowe the truly eclectic folk your way to fitness 1997 street cries 2001 and human nature 2003
lines.name: English

lines.value: after the suspension of the albion band as a full time group in 2002 hutchings put together another small group of up and coming folk musicians under the title rainbow chasers resulting in three albums some colours fly 2005 a brilliant light 2005 and fortune never sleeps 2006
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2008 he formed the lark rise band to perform and record music from his most successful show resulting in the album lark rise revisited 2008
lines.name: English

lines.value: he continues to tour in the christmas season with the albion christmas band and is plans future projects with ex albion band member ken nicol
lines.name: English

lines.value: his career has been celebrated with the release of archive series the guv'nor and burning bright 2005 a boxed set of four cds which contain many rare and previously unreleased recordings
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2006 hutchings received the prestigious good tradition trophy at the bbc radio 2 folk awards in recognition of his contributions to the genre and in 2007 he shared the special award for most influential folk album of all time for liege and lief
lines.name: English

lines.name: English

lines.value: he was awarded the mbe in the queen's birthday honours of 2015 for services to folk music

lines.value: the altamont corridor express also known as ace formerly altamont commuter express is a commuter rail service in california connecting stockton and san jose
lines.name: English

lines.value: ace is named for the altamont pass through which it runs
lines.name: English

lines.value: service is managed by the san joaquin regional rail commission and operations are contracted to herzog transit services using aar assigned reporting mark htsx
lines.name: English

lines.value: the route includes ten stops with travel time about 2 hours and 12 minutes end to end
lines.name: English

lines.value: the tracks are owned by union pacific railroad
lines.name: English

lines.value: ace uses bombardier bilevel coaches and mpi f40ph-3c locomotives
lines.name: English

lines.value: service began on october 19 1998 with two weekday round trips
lines.name: English

lines.value: a third round trip was added in may 2001 followed by a fourth round trip in october 2012
lines.name: English

lines.value: , average weekday ridership is 4900
lines.name: English

lines.value: under the aceforward program a number of improvements to the service are being considered
lines.name: English

lines.value: these include a rerouted line through tracy an extension to modesto and merced and connections to bart at union city and tri valley
lines.name: English

lines.value: by the 1980s three rapidly growing areas in california silicon valley the tri valley and the middle part of the central valley were poorly connected by public transit even as interstate 580 and interstate 680 became more congested
lines.name: English

lines.value: the three areas had connections to san francisco and oakland via caltrain and the amtrak san joaquin and later bart and capitol corridor trains but commuting from the central valley and tri valley to silicon valley required using a car or limited bus service
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1989 the san joaquin council of governments stockton chamber of commerce and the building industry association of the delta started work on a 20-year transportation plan for their section of the central valley
lines.name: English

lines.value: in november 1990 san joaquin county voters passed measure k a half cent sales tax to fund a variety of transportation improvements
lines.name: English

lines.value: the highest priority project was the establishment of passenger rail service to san jose
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1995 san joaquin county and seven cities along the route formed the san joaquin regional rail commission sjrrc to oversee the creation of the service
lines.name: English

lines.value: in may 1997 the altamont commuter express joint powers authority ace jpa was formed by the sjrrc santa clara valley transportation authority vta and alameda congestion management agency acma
lines.name: English

lines.value: that agreement formalized financial support administrative processes and governance for the rail service
lines.name: English

lines.value: the operation is funded by a variety of state and federal sources largely sales tax revenue collected by the three jpa signatories farebox revenues account for about one third of costs
lines.name: English

lines.value: cost sharing for capital projects excluding stations during the initial 36 months of service was determined by the jpa on a case by case basis and approved by each of the member agencies
lines.name: English

lines.value: the initial purchase of rolling stock construction of stations and other start up costs amounting to some $48 million were covered primarily by measure k funds
lines.name: English

lines.value: station improvements are the responsibility of the county in which the station is located
lines.name: English

lines.value: ace pays the owner of the right of way union pacific railroad about $1.5 million per year it also uses about 4 miles of caltrain track in san jose
lines.name: English

lines.value: service began on october 19 1998 which two daily round trips running to san jose in the morning and stockton in the evening
lines.name: English

lines.value: the original service used two trainsets each with 4 bilevel coach cars for a total seated capacity of 1120 passengers in each direction daily
lines.name: English

lines.value: in september 1999 the service reached 1000 daily riders per direction resulting in many trains running at capacity
lines.name: English

lines.value: on february 21 2000 a morning short turn between san jose and pleasanton was added using an existing trainset giving pleasanton and fremont a third inbound train to alleviate the crowding on the two earlier trains
lines.name: English

lines.value: the trip was added after ace funded $3 million in track improvements to reduce conflicts with union pacific freight trains and amtrak capitol corridor trains
lines.name: English

lines.value: by early 2001 ace regularly carried more than 700 daily standees
lines.name: English

lines.value: after additional equipment was bought the turn back train was replaced by a nearly full length trip originating at lathrop manteca on march 5 2001 trains also began stopping at santa clara station
lines.name: English

lines.value: although the third train added 560 seats in each direction it brought an immediate increase in 380 daily riders
lines.name: English

lines.value: ace then planned to add a fourth round trip later in the year with fifth and sixth round trips by 2006
lines.name: English

lines.value: however by late 2001 the deepening dot com recession was severely hurting ridership and expansion plans were put on hold
lines.name: English

lines.value: on june 30 2003 the ace jpa was dissolved in favor of a cooperative services agreement between the three member agencies
lines.name: English

lines.value: on january 6 2003 ace introduced the stockton solution shuttle allowing stockton passengers to use the ace trip which terminated at lathrop/manteca
lines.name: English

lines.value: the trip was extended to stockton on august 1 2005
lines.name: English

lines.value: at that time service to santa clara was suspended to allow for the construction of a second platform and pedestrian tunnel at the station
lines.name: English

lines.value: at this time three amtrak thruway motorcoach trips connecting to the san joaquin one to san jose and two to stockton were open to ace riders
lines.name: English

lines.value: on august 28 2006 ace added a fourth round trip which operated midday using one of the existing trainsets
lines.name: English

lines.value: on november 7 2006 san joaquin county voters approved a 20-year extension of measure k suffering from reducing funding due to the great recession ace cut the lightly used midday trip on november 2 2009
lines.name: English

lines.value: in may 2012 ace restored service to santa clara station
lines.name: English

lines.value: on october 1 2012 a fourth rush hour round trip was added running approximately one hour after existing trips
lines.name: English

lines.value: in december 2012 the service was rebranded from altamont commuter express to altamont corridor express to reflect plans for a broader scope of service
lines.name: English

lines.value: in march 2014 ace opened a $65 million 121000 sqft maintenance facility in stockton
lines.name: English

lines.value: on july 1 2015 management and governance of the san joaquin passed from caltrans to the new san joaquin joint powers authority
lines.name: English

lines.value: the sjjpa has nominal control over the sjrrc but delegates all responsibility over ace to the sjrrc
lines.name: English

lines.value: on march 7 2016 an ace train was derailed by a mudslide in niles canyon near sunol
lines.name: English

lines.value: the front car plunged into the rain swollen alameda creek
lines.name: English

lines.value: fourteen passengers were injured but there were no fatalities
lines.name: English

lines.value: in association with the california high speed rail cahsr project the ace system had been planned to be dramatically upgraded and expanded
lines.name: English

lines.value: beginning around 2008 initial plans called for the altamont corridor rail project to produce a high speed rail super ace capable of halving the travel time between the endpoints
lines.name: English

lines.value: as the cahsr project was scaled back and rerouted to pacheco pass several years later these plans were replaced with the more modest aceforward program
lines.name: English

lines.value: the san joaquin regional rail commission issued a notice of intent to proceed with an environmental impact statement in june 2013 this was released in 2017 and prioritized goals as either long term or short term
lines.name: English

lines.value: short term goals include track improvements a possible reroute through downtown tracy including new stations a west tracy station and a new extension to modesto in addition to additional daily round trips
lines.name: English

lines.value: long term goals include upgrades to the existing corridor to allow as many as 10 daily round trips extension to merced tunnels under altamont pass and electrification of the line from stockton to san jose
lines.name: English

lines.value: also to be studied are possible connections with bart at union city or livermore via traditional ace rail diesel multiple units or bus bridges
lines.name: English

lines.value: the state senate allocated $400 million in revenue from a gas tax increase to aceforward expansion
lines.name: English

lines.value: service may be extended to lodi and sacramento to provide more rail service and connections within the central valley
lines.name: English

lines.value: in january 2018 ace received road repair and accountability act funds in order to initiate saturday service
lines.name: English

lines.value: , ace operates four daily round trips all of which run westbound in the morning and eastbound in the evening
lines.name: English

lines.value: trains are scheduled to make the one way trip in 2 hours 12 minutes an average speed of 39 mph
lines.name: English

lines.value: from san jose to just north of santa clara ace uses the caltrain main line shared with caltrain and amtrak service
lines.name: English

lines.value: from santa clara to stockton the majority of the route ace runs on union pacific railroad freight lines
lines.name: English

lines.value: from santa clara to newark ace uses the coastal subdivision then the niles subdivision to niles
lines.name: English

lines.value: from niles to stockton the line uses the oakland subdivision
lines.name: English

lines.value: the route runs through niles canyon parallel to the niles canyon railway highway 84 and the hetch hetchy aqueduct
lines.name: English

lines.value: the line passes through a long tunnel which cuts off one of the canyon's horseshoes
lines.name: English

lines.value: this tunnel was modified from its original configuration to accommodate intermodal double stack freight trains
lines.name: English

lines.value: however this left the track in poor condition reducing speeds from to in the summer and as low as during the rainy season
lines.name: English

lines.value: the san joaquin regional rail commission plans to rehabilitate the tunnel
lines.name: English

lines.value: east of pleasanton and livermore the line runs through the altamont pass on the original feather river route
lines.name: English

lines.value: after crossing the california aqueduct and the delta mendota canal into the central valley skirting the southern edge of tracy
lines.name: English

lines.value: it then turns north between lathrop and manteca and runs to robert j cabral station in stockton
lines.name: English

lines.value: ace tickets are available at select stations and on ace's web site
lines.name: English

lines.value: distance based fares are available in one way round trip 20 trip weekly and monthly passes
lines.name: English

lines.value: ace operates push pull trains with a single diesel locomotive and six or seven bilevel coach cars
lines.name: English

lines.value: trains typically operate with the locomotive leading westbound and the cab car leading eastbound
lines.name: English

lines.value: the special investigation branch sib is the name given to the detective branches of all three british military police arms the royal navy police royal military police and royal air force police
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is most closely associated with the royal military police which has the largest sib
lines.name: English

lines.value: sib investigators usually operate in plain clothes although they may wear uniform when serving overseas
lines.name: English

lines.value: members are usually senior non commissioned officers sergeants or petty officers or above or commissioned officers although the royal air force sib employs corporals who perform the same function as all sib investigators
lines.name: English

lines.value: the royal navy sib is the smallest of the three sibs with the sio holding the rank of lieutenant commander
lines.name: English

lines.value: they investigate all incidents falling within schedule 2 of the armed forces act 2006
lines.name: English

lines.value: although an sib appears to have existed in the british army of the rhine in germany between 1919 and 1926 the origins of the army's sib are in 1940 when twenty scotland yard detectives were enlisted in the corps of military police to deal with the pilfering of military stores within the british expeditionary force bef in france
lines.name: English

lines.value: the unit was formed on the recommendations of detective chief inspector george hatherill who later went on to investigate the serial killers john reginald christie and john george haigh and the great train robbery and command was given to detective superintendent clarence campion head of scotland yard's criminal record office who was commissioned as a major
lines.name: English

lines.value: campion was hit in the head by shrapnel during the dunkirk evacuation and died on 20 may 1940 the only sib casualty of the bef
lines.name: English

lines.value: after this beginning the sib was established on a full time basis
lines.name: English

lines.value: one of the first group of detectives frank elliott was sent out to cairo egypt
lines.name: English

lines.value: under the supervision of colonel claude harper elliott managed a 500-man force which investigated crime in egypt palestine and later libya
lines.name: English

lines.value: the sib rmp now consists of about three hundred personnel including scenes of crime officers and forensic technicians
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is divided into numbered units called investigation platoons for instance 33 inv pl sib regt which are subdivided into detachments each usually commanded by a warrant officer class 2
lines.name: English

lines.value: there is a section or detachment on most major british army stations
lines.name: English

lines.value: there is also a territorial army section made up of cid officers and ex regular sib
lines.name: English

lines.value: the headquarters sib regiment is at campion lines at bulford wiltshire
lines.name: English

lines.value: within the rmp sib is known as the branch or more commonly the feds in 2006 the sib was subjected to an inspection by her majesty's inspectorate of constabulary hmic
lines.name: English

lines.value: the armed forces bill 2006 seeks to require the sib to refer investigations into inherently serious crimes directly to the service prosecuting authority spa rather than to commanding officers
lines.name: English

lines.value: sib recruit class 1 and 2 cpl's from the general police duties employment group of the royal military police and each candidate undergoes 12 months foundation training to determine suitability
lines.name: English

lines.value: during training an extensive testing phase is completed utilizing the distance learning package dlp coupled with a series of exams including the infamous entrance exam
lines.name: English

lines.value: students who successfully pass the entrance exam are eligible for further training on the serious crime investigation course scic a 9-week residential course held at the defence school of policing and guarding southwick park fareham
lines.name: English

lines.value: on completion successful candidates are placed onto a merit board awaiting full time employment as an sib investigator
lines.name: English

lines.value: passing the scic does not automatically qualify candidates employment with the sib and all candidates who were successful in passing the scic but unsuitable for employment with the sib will be returned to their respective unit as a level 3 trained investigator
lines.name: English

lines.value: the royal air force police special investigations branch formed in 1918 has the distinction of being the only branch specific investigative unit entrusted with a major war crime
lines.name: English

lines.value: five officers and fourteen ncos were given the assignment of investigating the stalag luft iii murders immediately following the second world war
lines.name: English

lines.value: in direct recognition of this the raf police sib was granted permission to use the great escape march as its distinct march by cas in 2015
lines.name: English

lines.value: the royal air force police currently has two sib squadrons sib north based at raf college cranwell and sib south based at raf halton these squadrons are within no 3 specialist police wing
lines.name: English

lines.value: personnel undertake the serious crime investigation course scic before going on to complete a number of home office courses such as soit national drugs and tier 23 & 5 interviewer family liaison officer specialist fraud etc.the raf police sib differs slightly from its rmp counterparts in terms of rank structure employing a mix of corporals and sergeants
lines.name: English

lines.value: both sib(s and sib(n additionally employ a number of acting corporals
lines.name: English

lines.value: sib personnel extensively deployed with their rmp sib counterparts throughout the duration of op banner northern ireland op telic iraq and op herrick afghanistan in support of combat operations
lines.name: English

lines.value: her majesty's inspectorate of constabulary conducted an inspection of the rafp sib in 2009

lines.value: the name of sweden swedish sverige ) is ultimately derived from the ethnonym of the swedes
lines.name: English

lines.value: the english name was loaned from dutch in the 17th century to refer to sweden as an emerging great power
lines.name: English

lines.value: before sweden's imperial expansion early modern english used swedeland
lines.name: English

lines.value: the old english name of sweden was sweoland or sweorice land or realm of the sweonas the germanic tribes of the sviar old norse svibjoo
lines.name: English

lines.value: the name of the sviar itself is derived from a proto norse *swihoniz presumably a self designation containing the germanic reflexive *swe one's own self
lines.name: English

lines.value: the modern english name sweden was loaned from dutch
lines.name: English

lines.value: before the gradual introduction of sweden in the 17th century english used swedeland
lines.name: English

lines.value: it is based on middle dutch zweden the dutch name of sweden and in origin the dative plural of zwede swede
lines.name: English

lines.value: it has been in use in english from about 1600 first recorded in scottish swethin swadne
lines.name: English

lines.value: country names based on a dative plural in n became productive in german and dutch in the 15th century compare german italien italy spanien spain rumanien romania ungarn hungary
lines.name: English

lines.value: outside of dutch zweden german schweden and english the name sweden has also been adopted in welsh
lines.name: English

lines.value: the english form in n has also influenced a number of non european languages including yoruba swidin and the chinese rendition  pinyin ruidian and via the chinese hanzi spelling various other languages in the larger sinosphere such as vietnamese thy din southern min sui-tian etc
lines.name: English

lines.value: in sweden the form swerike is attested from the end of the 13th century svearike from the 14th century as well as the icelandic sviariki and the old gutnish suiariki
lines.name: English

lines.value: in those days the meaning was restricted to the older swedish region in svealand and did not always include gotaland the land of the geats
lines.name: English

lines.value: the word rike translates to realm and also appears in the name of the legislature riksdag c.f danish rigsdag german reichstag
lines.name: English

lines.value: towards the end of the 15th century the form had changed to swerighe both in swedish and danish like bakare baker to bagare and mik me to mig
lines.name: English

lines.value: 17th-century spellings include swerghe swirghe swirge
lines.name: English

lines.value: much is made about the difference between the medieval forms svearike and sverige

lines.value: great chalfield manor is an english country house at great chalfield about northeast of the town of bradford on avon in the west of the county of wiltshire
lines.name: English

lines.value: pevsner describes great chalfield as one of the most perfect examples of the late medieval english manor house
lines.name: English

lines.value: the moated manor house was built around 1465 1480 for thomas tropenell a modest member of the landed gentry who made a fortune as a clothier
lines.name: English

lines.value: the independent hall lit on both sides is flanked by unusually symmetrical gabled cross wings with oriel windows and lower gabled porches in the inner corners in the north facing former entrance court for which the richest effects were reserved
lines.name: English

lines.value: its external symmetry unusual for its date is superficial
lines.name: English

lines.value: the intimately connected parish church largely rebuilt by tropnell also faces into the court which was formerly entered obliquely through a gatehouse in the west wing nicholas cooper observes of the church that the probable need to pass through the house's forecourt in order to reach it neatly demonstrates the community of secular and religious authority
lines.name: English

lines.value: part of a moat survives but the forecourt has been opened up to the outside in a manner that changes its original inward facing aspect
lines.name: English

lines.value: the house was altered substantially with some of the original character lost after the neale family commissioned the architect thomas larkins walker a pupil of pugin to carry out a detailed survey of the manor in 1836 though his restoration proposals of 1837 were never carried out the house was reduced and in particular the great hall adapted as a farmhouse lost its ornate ceiling with only one of the original bosses surviving
lines.name: English

lines.value: externally there is a garden with four tree houses groups of four clipped yews that have grown together and been hollowed out inside to allow one to walk through
lines.name: English

lines.value: the house and garden were purchased by george fuller mp of neston park in the early 1900s and restored and furnished between 1905 and 1911 by his fourth son major robert fuller under the guidance of sir harold brakspear
lines.name: English

lines.value: the restoration included a sympathetic garden design by alfred parsons
lines.name: English

lines.value: robert fuller gave the property to the national trust in 1943 and it is open to the public

lines.value: robert floyd grandson of robert fuller and his family live here and manage the property for the trust
lines.name: English

lines.value: tours of the house are at fixed times and visitors are escorted by a guide

lines.value: the house is grade i listed the tropenell cartulary manuscript compiled for thomas tropenell is still kept there

lines.value: all saints church near the front of the house is a small church dating from the 14th century

lines.value: commodore oscar charles badger 12 august 1823 in mansfield connecticut - 20 june 1899 in concord massachusetts was an officer of the united states navy who served in the mexican american and american civil wars

lines.value: badger received an appointment as a midshipman in the united states navy on 9 september 1841 and after a tour of duty in the served in along the atlantic coast of africa

lines.value: by 1850 he was posted to the pacific squadron and served successively in the the frigate , and the sloop

lines.value: he returned to shore in 1853 for a tour of duty at the united states naval observatory located in washington dc in 1855 he returned to the pacific squadron for duty in the sloop and that autumn participated in an expedition to the fiji islands to redress wrongs suffered by members of the crews of american whalers and merchant ships at the hands of natives

lines.value: the national labor party was formed by australian prime minister billy hughes in 1916 following the 1916 labor split on the issue of world war i conscription in australia
lines.name: English

lines.value: hughes had taken over as leader of the australian labor party and prime minister of australia when anti conscriptionist andrew fisher resigned in 1915
lines.name: English

lines.value: he formed the new party for himself and his followers after he was expelled from the alp a month after the 1916 plebiscite on conscription in australia
lines.name: English

lines.value: hughes held a pro conscription stance in relation to world war i
lines.name: English

lines.value: on 15 september 1916 the executive of the political labour league the labor party organisation in new south wales at the time expelled hughes from the labor party
lines.name: English

lines.value: when the federal parliamentary labor caucus met on 14 november 1916 lengthy discussions ensued until hughes walked out with 24 other labor members the remaining 43 members of caucus then passed their motion of no confidence in the leadership effectively expelling hughes and the other members
lines.name: English

lines.value: hughes and his followers who included several early labor leaders formed a minority government supported by the commonwealth liberal party led by another labor dissident joseph cook
lines.name: English

lines.value: believing the labor party was no longer sufficiently nationalist they began laying the groundwork for a new party that would be both socially radical and nationalist
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 1917 hughes and cook turned their confidence and supply agreement into a formal party the nationalist party of australia
lines.name: English

lines.value: hughes became the merged party's leader with cook as his deputy
lines.name: English

lines.value: although it was essentially an upper and middle class party dominated by former liberals the presence of several labor men allowed the party to project an image of national unity
lines.name: English

lines.value: the national labor party was never formally constituted itself as a party and had no organisational structure although some trade union officials and labor party branches particularly in western australia and tasmania supported it
lines.name: English

lines.value: the national labor movement in western australia started off as two separate groups one known as the labor solidarity committee based out of trades hall in perth and the other known as national labor and based on the goldfields
lines.name: English

lines.value: the two merged in april may 1917 with former premier john scaddan as their leader
lines.name: English

lines.value: however by july he was without a seat in parliament and the party turned to federal senators patrick lynch hugh de largie and george pearce for leadership and guidance
lines.name: English

lines.value: unlike its federal counterpart it maintained its own distinct identity and structure and worked with the nationalists as coalition partners
lines.name: English

lines.value: a number of western australian unions disaffiliated from the australian labor federation to support the national labor movement most notably those representing the engine drivers railway employees boilermakers and carpenters which were powerful in the goldfields
lines.name: English

lines.value: organisationally however the party was believed to be over dependent on its senate patrons and struggled to build a genuine extraparliamentary organisation
lines.name: English

lines.value: the party scored six of 50 assembly seats in each of the 1917 and 1921 elections and held three of 30 council seats during this period
lines.name: English

lines.value: however in the 1924 elections their representation was reduced to one in the assembly and two in the council many through the defeat of sitting nlp members by labor candidates and later that year what remained of the party was subsumed by the nationalists

lines.value: philip brown born 30 may 1959 is an english former professional footballer coach and manager
lines.name: English

lines.value: he is currently the manager of league two side swindon town
lines.name: English

lines.value: as a player brown was a right back who made over six hundred league appearances in an eighteen year career but never made it to the top flight
lines.name: English

lines.value: however as a manager he became the first to lead hull city to the top division in their 104-year history winning the championship play offs in 2008 after a 1 0 win against bristol city at wembley
lines.name: English

lines.value: since 2011 brown has appeared as a match summariser on bbc radio 5 live as well as the station's sport panel show fighting talk winning for the first time on 5 may 2012
lines.name: English

lines.value: born in south shields county durham and educated in the north east brown started his career playing sunday league football for south shields side red duster in the south shields business houses league in the same team as ray dunbar and bobby davison who went on to play for derby county and leeds united
lines.name: English

lines.value: as a professional brown played at full back for many years with hartlepool united followed by a spell at halifax town with fellow north easterner billy ayre at both clubs and under him at the latter in 1988 he moved to bolton wanderers winning the associate members cup in 1989
lines.name: English

lines.value: brown joined blackpool in 1994 playing under sam allardyce until 1996 while also being his assistant manager
lines.name: English

lines.value: brown started taking his coaching badges while playing for bolton encouraged by bruce rioch
lines.name: English

lines.value: his first coaching role was as assistant to sam allardyce at blackpool
lines.name: English

lines.value: he returned to bolton wanderers after his playing career ended and served as assistant manager to colin todd
lines.name: English

lines.value: following todd's departure in 1999 he took charge of the team as caretaker manager winning four games out of five until the appointment of sam allardyce
lines.name: English

lines.value: he then served as allardyce's assistant for six years before deciding to forge his own career as a manager
lines.name: English

lines.value: brown's first full time senior management position was at derby county where he succeeded george burley in june 2005
lines.name: English

lines.value: his time at derby county proved to be unsuccessful and he was sacked just seven months into his tenure in january 2006 after a 6 1 league defeat against coventry city followed by a 3 1 defeat to colchester in the fa cup fourth round
lines.name: English

lines.value: derby were in 19th place when brown departed
lines.name: English

lines.value: brown was appointed as first team coach at hull city on 27 october 2006 under phil parkinson and took over as joint caretaker manager alongside colin murphy on 4 december 2006 after parkinson's sacking with hull in 22nd place in the football league championship
lines.name: English

lines.value: after taking hull out of the relegation zone with three wins and a draw in the six matches as caretaker manager he was appointed as the permanent manager of the club on 4 january 2007
lines.name: English

lines.value: brown went on to lead the tigers to championship safety and the following season hull city won promotion to the top level of english football for the first time in the club's 104-year history by beating bristol city at wembley in the championship play off final on 24 may 2008
lines.name: English

lines.value: brown described this as the best day of my life without a shadow of a doubt
lines.name: English

lines.value: brown was rewarded with a new three year contract which he signed on the weekend of hull city's first ever top flight match a 2 1 victory over fulham on 16 august 2008
lines.name: English

lines.value: on 28 september brown managed hull to a 2 1 victory at arsenal
lines.name: English

lines.value: it was only arsenal's second ever defeat at the emirates stadium and was described by the hull press as the greatest victory in the club's history
lines.name: English

lines.value: after a 1 0 victory at bottom of the table tottenham hotspur the following weekend and a 3 0 away victory at the also newly promoted west bromwich albion he was awarded the manager of the month award for hull's performances in september
lines.name: English

lines.value: the first nine games hull spent as a top division club resulted in six wins as they occupied third place in the premier league and were only being kept off the top by liverpool and arsenal having superior goal difference
lines.name: English

lines.value: the remainder of the season was not so easy for brown as the team struggled to pick up the remaining points necessary to avoid relegation and he was involved in several controversial incidents
lines.name: English

lines.value: in november 2008 he was fined 1000 and warned about his future conduct by the fa after he admitted a charge of improper conduct
lines.name: English

lines.value: the charge related to a game against wigan in august which hull lost 5 0
lines.name: English

lines.value: on 26 december 2008 following a poor first half performance by hull in a league match against manchester city brown conducted his half time team talk on the pitch in full view of the crowd and at the end of the pitch where the hull supporters had been sitting
lines.name: English

lines.value: the festival of german language literature is a literary event which takes place annually in klagenfurt austria
lines.name: English

lines.value: during this major literary festival which lasts for several days a number of awards are given the major one being the ingeborg bachmann prize first awarded in 1977 and one of the most important awards for literature in the german language
lines.name: English

lines.value: in the mid seventies the journalist and writer humbert fink and the chairman of the austrian radio and tv orf studio in carinthia at that time ernst willner decided to establish a literary competition based on an event held by gruppe 47
lines.name: English

lines.value: they were able to enlist marcel reich ranicki amongst others onto the original jury
lines.name: English

lines.value: the result was the festival of german language literature which has taken place annually since 1977 and is televised live by orf
lines.name: English

lines.value: the main prize of the festival is given in memory of ingeborg bachmann 25 june 1926 - 17 october 1973 one of the most distinguished austrian writers
lines.name: English

lines.value: the prize winner is determined during a three day reading event in which the invited candidates present their literary contributions which have to be unpublished to the nine member professional jury and the public
lines.name: English

lines.value: each presentation is about 25 minutes long and the original language of these contributions must be german
lines.name: English

lines.value: a moderator presents and guides the readings and the discussions of the jury and the writers have to convince both the jury and the public of the quality of their contributions
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2008 the jury was reduced to seven members the competing writers from eighteen to fourteen
lines.name: English

lines.value: since 2006 the ingeborg bachmann prize has been endowed with 25000 eur
lines.name: English

lines.value: in 2009 a total of 56500 eur was awarded to the participants
lines.name: English

lines.value: several other literature prizes are awarded during the festival in total usually three to five awards
lines.name: English

lines.value: over the years additional sponsored prizes have been awarded
lines.name: English

lines.value: robert bob slavin is an american psychologist who studies educational and academic issues

lines.value: his success for all educational model has been influential in american academic reform since its inception in 1987

lines.value: he has also influenced the research on cooperative learning publishing numerous seminal reviews of literature including meta analyses and best evidence syntheses on cooperative learning
